'''Eduard Jacob Neven Looijenga''' (born 30 September 1948, [[Zaandam]])<ref>[http://www.albumacademicum.uva.nl/cgi/b/bib/bib-idx?type=boolean;lang=nl;searchtype=phd;c=ap;q1=looijenga;rgn1=entirerecord;op2=And;rgn2=entirerecord;op3=And;rgn3=entirerecord;op4=And;rgn4=entirerecord;date1=1576;date2=1989;date61=1634;date62=2013;cc=ap;view=reslist;sort=achternaam;fmt=long;page=reslist;start=1;size=1 Prof. dr. E.J.N. Looijenga, 1948 -] at Album Academicum, Universiteit van Amsterdam</ref> is a [[Dutch people|Dutch]] mathematician who works in [[algebraic geometry]] and the theory of [[algebraic group]]s.<ref name="knaw">[https://www.knaw.nl/en/members/members/4490 Member profile], KNAW, retrieved 2015-01-26.</ref> He was a professor of mathematics at [[Utrecht University]] until his retirement in 2013.<ref name="singular">[http://www.projects.science.uu.nl/singularlife/Singular_life/Singular_life.html A singular life: in honour of Eduard Looijenga], Utrecht Univ., retrieved 2015-01-26.</ref>

Looijenga studied mathematics at the [[University of Amsterdam]] beginning in 1965, and earned a master's degree there in 1971. He obtained a Dutch fellowship for two years of study at the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]] in France, and then returned to the University of Amsterdam, earning a Ph.D. in 1974 under the supervision of [[Nicolaas Kuiper]].<ref name="cv">[http://www.staff.science.uu.nl/~looij101/CV_%26_More.html Curriculum vitae], retrieved 2015-01-26.</ref><ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=49687}}</ref> After postdoctoral research at the [[University of Liverpool]], he took a faculty position at the [[Radboud University Nijmegen|University of Nijmegen]] in 1975, returned as a professor to the University of Amsterdam in 1987, and moved again to Utrecht in 1991. Since his 2013 retirement, he has also held a professorship at [[Tsinghua University]].<ref name="cv"/>

In 1978, Looijenga was an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]].<ref name="cv"/> He became a member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1995,<ref name="knaw"/> and in 2012 he became one of the inaugural [[fellow]]s of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2015-01-25.</ref>
In 2013, a conference in honor of his retirement was held at Utrecht University.<ref name="singular"/>

{{Japanese name|Matsushima}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Yozo Matsushima |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1921|02|11}} |birth_place = [[Sakai City]], [[Osaka Prefecture]], [[Japan]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1983|04|09|1921|02|11}} |death_place = [[Osaka]], Japan |nationality = [[Japan]]ese |fields = [[Mathematics]] |workplaces = [[Osaka University]]

[[University of Notre Dame]] |alma_mater = Osaka University |doctoral_advisor = [[Kenjiro Shoda]] |doctoral_students = |known_for = research in [[Lie algebra]]s and [[Lie group]]s |awards = [[Asahi Prize]] }} {{Nihongo|'''Yozo Matsushima'''|松島 与三|Matsushima Yozō|extra=February 11, 1921 – April 9, 1983}} was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[mathematician]]. ==Early life== Matsushima was born on February 11, 1921 in [[Sakai City]], [[Osaka Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. He studied at Osaka Imperial University (later named [[Osaka University]]) and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in mathematics in September 1942.{{cite journal |last=Murakami |first=Shingo |authorlink= |year=1984 |month= |title=Yozô Matsushima: 1921--1983 |journal=The Osaka Journal of Mathematics |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=i–ii |id= |url=http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS?service=UI&version=1.0&verb=Display&handle=euclid.ojm/1200776862 |accessdate=2008-07-09}} At Osaka, he was taught by mathematicians [[Kenjiro Shoda]]. After completing his degree, he was appointed as an assistant in the Mathematical Institute of Nagoya Imperial University (later named [[Nagoya University]]). These were difficult years for Japanese students and researchers because of [[World War II]].{{MacTutor Biography|id=Matsushima}} The first paper published by Matsushima contained a proof that a conjecture of [[Hans Zassenhaus]] was false. Zassenhaus had conjectured that every semisimple [[Lie algebra]] ''L'' over a field of prime characteristic, with [''L'', ''L''] = ''L'', is the direct sum of simple ideals. Matsushima constructed a counterexample. He then developed a proof that Cartan subalgebras of a complex Lie algebra are conjugate. However, Japanese researchers were out of touch with the research done in the West, and Matsushima was unaware that [[France|French]] mathematician [[Claude Chevalley]] had already published a proof. When he obtained details of another paper of Chevalley through a review in Mathematical Reviews, he was able to construct the proofs for himself. Matsushima published two papers in the 1947 volume of the Proceedings of the Japan Academy (which did not appear until 1950) and three papers in the first volume of Journal of the Mathematical Society of Japan. ==Professorship== Matsushima became a full professor at Nagoya University in 1953. Chevalley visited Matsushima in Nagoya in 1953 and invited him to spend the following year in France. He went to France in 1954 and returned to Nagoya in December 1955. He also spent time at the [[University of Strasbourg]]. He presented some of his results to Ehresmann's seminar in Strasbourg, extending Cartan's classification of complex irreducible Lie algebras to the case of real Lie algebras. In spring 1960, Matsushima became a professor of Osaka University as successor to the chair of Shoda. His research took a somewhat different direction and he wrote a series of papers on cohomology of locally symmetric spaces, collaborating with Murakami. He went to the Institute for Advanced Study in September 1962 and returned to Osaka after one year. He jointly began to organize the United States-Japan Seminar in Differential Geometry, which was held in Kyoto in June 1965. After this, he went to France and spent the academic year 1965-66 as visiting professor at the University of Grenoble. He accepted a chair at the [[University of Notre Dame]] in [[Notre Dame, Indiana]] in September 1966. He continued to collaborate with Murakami. He introduced [[Matsushima's formula]] for the Betti numbers of quotients of symmetric spaces. In 1967, he became an editor of the Journal of Differential Geometry and remained on the editorial board for the rest of his life. After 14 years at Notre Dame, he returned to Japan in 1980. A conference was organized in his honor in May 1980 before he left Notre Dame. ==Later life== In February 1981, a volume of papers ''Manifolds and Lie groups, Papers in honour of Yozo Matsushima'' was published by his colleagues and former students at Osaka. It also contained some papers presented to the conference held in Notre Dame in the previous May. He died on April 9, 1983 in Osaka, Japan. ==Honours== Matsushima received the [[Asahi Prize]] for his research on [[continuous group]]s in 1962. == References == {{reflist}} * {{cite journal |last=Kobayashi |first=Shoshichi |year=1984 |title=The mathematical work of Y. Matsushima and its development |journal=The Osaka Journal of Mathematics |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=iii–xix |url=http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS?service=UI&version=1.0&verb=Display&handle=euclid.ojm/1200776863 |accessdate=2008-07-10 }} *{{Citation | last1=Matsushima | first1=Yozô | editor1-last=Murakami | editor1-first=Shingo | editor2-last=Kobayashi | editor2-first=Shoshichi | title=Collected papers of Yozô Matsushima | publisher=World Scientific Publishing Co. Inc. | location=River Edge, NJ | series=Series in Pure Mathematics | isbn=9789810208141 | doi=10.1142/9789814360067 |mr=1169467 | year=1992 | volume=15}} * {{cite journal |year=1984 |title=List of publications of Yozô Matsushima |journal=The Osaka Journal of Mathematics |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=xx–xxii |url=http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS?service=UI&version=1.0&verb=Display&handle=euclid.ojm/1200776864 |accessdate=2008-07-10 }} *{{mathgenealogy|id=126487}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matsushima, Yozo}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Japanese mathematicians]] [[Category:Japanese mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Group theorists]] [[Category:Osaka University alumni]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame faculty]] [[Category:Nagoya University faculty]] [[Category:Osaka University faculty]] [[Category:People from Sakai, Osaka]]

[[Breakthrough Prize]](2018) }} '''James McKernan''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 1964) is a [[mathematician]], and a professor of mathematics at [[University of California, San Diego|UCSD]] in the [[United States]]. He was a professor at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] from 2007 until 2013. McKernan was the joint winner of the [[Cole Prize]] in 2009,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/ams/press/cole-2009.html|title=Christopher Hacon and James McKernan Receive 2009 AMS Cole Prize in Algebra|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|date=2009-01-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ia.ucsb.edu/93106/2009/February9/cole.html|title=Mathematics Professor Receives Cole Prize|publisher=[[University of California, Santa Barbara]]|date=2009-02-09}} and joint recipient of the [[Clay Research Award]] in 2007.{{Cite web|url=http://www.claymath.org/research_award/McKernan/ |title=Clay Research Award, 2007 |publisher=[[Clay Mathematics Institute]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613005225/http://claymath.org/research_award/McKernan/ |archivedate=2010-06-13 |df= }} Both honors were received jointly with his colleague [[Christopher Hacon]]. He gave an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited talk at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 2010, on the topic of "Algebraic Geometry".{{cite web|title=ICM Plenary and Invited Speakers since 1897|url=http://www.mathunion.org/db/ICM/Speakers/SortedByCongress.php|publisher=[[International Congress of Mathematicians]]}} He was the joint winner (with [[Christopher Hacon]]) of the 2018 [[Breakthrough Prize in Mathematics]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.math.ucsd.edu/~jmckerna/}} *{{MathGenealogy |id=42404 }} *[http://www.ams.org/notices/200904/rtx090400494p.pdf Citation for 2009 Cole Prize in Algebra] *[http://www.claymath.org/library/research_award/corti.pdf THe work of Hacon and McKernan] {{Breakthrough Prize laureates}} {{FRS 2011}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKernan, James}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:20th-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Santa Barbara faculty]] [[Category:Clay Research Award recipients]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Simons Investigator]] {{UK-mathematician-stub}}

pages.title: William Messing
pages.text:
[[File:William Messing.jpg|thumb|William Messing in Oberwolfach, 2008]]
'''William Messing''' is an [[United States|American]] mathematician who works in the field of [[arithmetic algebraic geometry]].

Messing received his doctorate in 1971 at [[Princeton University]] under the supervisions of [[Alexander Grothendieck]] (and [[Nicholas Katz]]) with his thesis entitled ''The Crystals Associated to Barsotti–Tate Groups: With Applications to Abelian Schemes.''<ref>[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=11998 Mathematics Genealogy Project]</ref> In 1972, he was a [[C.L.E. Moore instructor]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. He is currently a professor at the [[University of Minnesota]] ([[Minneapolis]]).

In his thesis, Messing elaborated on [[Alexander Grothendieck|Grothendieck]]'s 1970 lecture at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Nice]] on p-divisible groups ([[Barsotti–Tate group]]s) that are important in algebraic geometry in prime characteristic, which were introduced in the 1950s by [[Jean Dieudonné|Dieudonné]] in his study of Lie algebras over fields of finite characteristic. Messing worked together with [[Pierre Berthelot]], [[Barry Mazur]] and [[Aise Johan de Jong]].

== Writings ==
* Pierre Berthelot, Messing, ''Theorie de Dieudonné cristalline I,'' Journées de Geometrie Algebrique de Rennes, 1978, volume 1, pp. 17–37, Asterisque, volume 63, 1979
* Pierre Berthelot, Lawrence Breen, Messing, ''Theorie de Dieudonné cristalline II,'' Springer Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Volume 930, 1982
* With Berthelot, ''Theorie de Dieudonné cristalline III,'' in Paul Cartier and others, Grothendieck Festschrift, Volume 1, 1990, Springer, p. 173
* Barry Mazur, Messing, Universal extensions and one dimensional cristalline cohomology, Springer Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Volume 370, 1974
* Messing, The crystals associated to Barsotti–Tate groups: with applications to abelian schemes, Springer Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Volume 264, 1972

'''Rosa M. Miró-Roig''' (born August 6, 1960)<ref>Birth date from [http://www.isni.org/isni/0000000116260980 ISNI authority control file], retrieved 2018-11-29.</ref> is a professor of [[mathematics]] at the [[University of Barcelona]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.imub.ub.edu/index.php?option=com_jresearch&view=member&task=show&id=20&Itemid=182|title=Rosa Maria Miró-Roig|website=www.imub.ub.edu|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref> specializing in [[algebraic geometry]] and [[commutative algebra]]. She did her graduate studies at the [[University of Barcelona]], earning a Ph.D. in 1985 under the supervision of Sebastià Xambó-Descamps with a thesis entitled ''Haces reflexivos sobre espacios proyectivos''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=92843|title=Rosa Miró-Roig - The Mathematics Genealogy Project|website=www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref> 

== Books and editing ==
Miró-Roig has authored and co-authored three mathematics research volumes. Most recently, she co-authored ''On the Shape of a Pure O-sequence'' ([[American Mathematical Society]] 2012) with Mats Boij, Juan C. Migliore, Uwe Nagel, and Fabrizio Zanello.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review by Adam L. Van Tuyl|last=|first=|date=|mr = 2931681}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=On the shape of a pure O-sequence|date=2011|publisher=American Mathematical Society|others=Boij, Mats, 1969-|isbn=9780821869109|location=Providence, R.I.|oclc=782251800}}</ref> Previously, she authored the research text ''Determinantal Ideals'' ([[Birkhäuser]] 2007)<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review by Juan C. Migliore|last=|first=|date=|mr = 2375719}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Determinantal ideals|last=M.|first=Miró-Roig, Rosa|date=2008|publisher=Birkhäuser|isbn=9783764385354|location=Basel|oclc=233974116}}</ref> and co-authored the monograph ''Gorenstein Liaison, Complete Intersection Liaison Invariants and Unobstructedness'' (American Mathematical Society 2001) with Jan O. Kleppe, Juan C. Migliore, Uwe Nagel, and Chris Peterson.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review by Scott R. Nollet|last=|first=|date=|mr = 1848976}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Gorenstein liaison, complete intersection liaison invariants, and unobstructedness|date=2001|publisher=American Mathematical Society|others=Kleppe, Jan O. (Jan Oddvar), 1947-|isbn=978-0821827383|location=Providence, R.I.|oclc=47002207}}</ref>

Miró-Roig is the Chief Editor of the mathematics research journal ''[[Collectanea Mathematica]]'' ([[Springer Nature|Springer]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.springer.com/mathematics/applications/journal/13348?detailsPage=editorialBoard|title=Collectanea Mathematica - incl. option to publish open access (Editorial Board)|website=springer.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=Collectanea Mathematica|journal = Collectanea Mathematica|doi = 10.1007/13348.2038-4815}}</ref> Also, she is on the editorial boards of the mathematics research journals ''Beiträge zur Algebra und Geometrie / Contributions to Algebra and Geometry'' (Springer)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.springer.com/mathematics/algebra/journal/13366/PS2?detailsPage=editorialBoard|title=Beiträge zur Algebra und Geometrie / Contributions to Algebra and Geometry - incl. option to publish open access (Editorial Board)|website=springer.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=Beiträge zur Algebra und Geometrie / Contributions to Algebra and Geometry|journal = Beiträge zur Algebra und Geometrie / Contributions to Algebra and Geometry|doi = 10.1007/13366.2191-0383|citeseerx = 10.1.1.614.5637}}</ref> and ''[[Journal of Commutative Algebra]]'' (Rocky Mountain Mathematics Consortium).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rmmc.asu.edu/jca/editors.html|title=Journal of Commutative Algebra Editorial Board|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Furthermore, she co-edited the mathematics research volumes ''Projective Varieties with Unexpected Properties'' ([[Walter de Gruyter|De Gruyter]] 2008) with Ciro Ciliberto, Antony V. Geramita, Brian Harbourne, and Kristian Ranestad,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review|last=|first=|date=|mr = 2201829}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Projective varieties with unexpected properties : a volume in memory of Giuseppe Veronese : proceedings of the international conference "Varieties with Unexpected Properties," Siena, Italy, June 8-13, 2004|date=2005|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|others=Veronese, Giuseppe, 1854-1917., Ciliberto, C. (Ciro), 1950-|isbn=9783110199703|location=Berlin|oclc=228144658}}</ref> ''European Congress of Mathematics: Barcelona, July 10–14, 2000'' (Birkhäuser 2001) two volumes with Carles Casacuberta, Joan Verdera, and Sebastià Xambó-Descamps,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review|last=|first=|date=|mr = 1905309}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=European Congress of Mathematics : Barcelona, July 10-14, 2000|date=2001|publisher=Birkhäuser|others=Casacuberta, Carlos, 1964-|isbn=978-3764364199|location=Basel|oclc=48053801}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review|last=|first=|date=|mr = 1905345}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=European Congress of Mathematics : Barcelona, July 10-14, 2000|date=2001|publisher=Birkhäuser|others=Casacuberta, Carlos, 1964-|isbn=978-3764364199|location=Basel|oclc=48053801}}</ref> ''Six Lectures on Commutative Algebra'' (Birkhäuser 1998) with J. Elias, J. M. Giral, and S. Zarzuela,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review|last=|first=|date=|mr = 1648663}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Six lectures on commutative algebra|date=1998|publisher=Birkhäuser Verlag|others=Elias, J. (Juan)|isbn=978-3764359515|location=Basel|oclc=39051720}}</ref> and ''Complex Analysis and Geometry'' (Chapman and Hall/CRC 1997) with V. Ancona, E. Ballico, and A. Silva<ref>{{Cite journal|title=MathSciNet review|last=|first=|date=|mr = 1477435}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Complex analysis and geometry|date=1997|publisher=Longman|others=Ancona, Vincenzo.|isbn=978-0582292765|location=Essex, England|oclc=35243565}}</ref>

In 2007, Miró-Roig was awarded the [[Ferran Sunyer i Balaguer Prize]] for her work "''Lectures on Determinantal Ideals'' (Progress in Mathematics n.264, Birkhäuser)".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ffsb.espais.iec.cat/en/the-ferran-sunyer-i-balaguer-prize/|title=The Ferran Sunyer i Balaguer Prize {{!}} Fundació Ferran Sunyer i Balaguer|website=ffsb.espais.iec.cat|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>

{{nihongo|'''Shinichi Mochizuki'''|望月 新一|Mochizuki Shin'ichi|extra=born March 29, 1969}} is a Japanese mathematician working in [[number theory]] and [[arithmetic geometry]]. He is one of the main contributors to [[anabelian geometry]]. His contributions include his solution of the [[Anabelian geometry#Formulation of a conjecture of Grothendieck on curves|Grothendieck conjecture in anabelian geometry]] about hyperbolic curves over number fields. Mochizuki has also worked in [[Hodge–Arakelov theory]] and [[p-adic Teichmüller theory]]. Mochizuki developed [[inter-universal Teichmüller theory]] which, due to its nature and applications, has attracted a high level of attention of non-mathematicians.{{sfn|Crowell|2017}}

==Biography==

=== Early life ===
Shinichi Mochizuki was born to parents Kiichi and Anne Mochizuki.<ref>[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/philly/obituary.aspx?n=leah-p-rauch-edelman&pid=3251930 Leah P. (Edelman) Rauch] Philly.com on Mar. 6, 2005</ref> When he was five years old, Shinichi Mochizuki and his family left Japan to live in the USA. His father was Fellow of Center for International Affairs and Center for Middle Eastern Studies at Harvard University (1974-76).<ref>[http://www.us-japan.org/otr/bios/mochizuki.html MOCHIZUKI, Kiichi Dr.] National Association of Japan-America Societies, Inc. </ref> Mochizuki attended [[Phillips Exeter Academy]] and graduated in 1985.<ref name="PWB">{{cite news |url=http://libserv23.princeton.edu/princetonperiodicals/cgi-bin/princetonperiodicals?a=d&d=WeeklyBulletin19880620-01.1.4&e=-------en-20--1--txt-IN-----%23 |title=Seniors address commencement crowd |work=Princeton Weekly Bulletin |volume=77 |page=4 |date=20 June 1988 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130403083550/http://libserv23.princeton.edu/princetonperiodicals/cgi-bin/princetonperiodicals?a=d&d=WeeklyBulletin19880620-01.1.4&e=-------en-20--1--txt-IN-----%23 |archivedate=3 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> He entered Princeton University as an undergraduate at age 16 and graduated [[salutatorian]] in 1988.<ref name="PWB" /> He then received a Ph.D. under the supervision of [[Gerd Faltings]] at age 23.<ref name="cv"/> After his PhD, Mochizuki spent two years at Harvard and then in 1994 moved back to Japan to join the [[Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences]] in [[Kyoto University]] (RIMS) in 1992 and was promoted to professor in 2002.<ref name="cv"/>{{sfn|Castelvecchi|2015}}

===Career===
Mochizuki proved [[Anabelian geometry#Formulation of a conjecture of Grothendieck on curves|Grothendieck conjecture on anabelian geometry]] in 1996. He was an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elib.zib.de/ICM98/B/3/3/|title=International Congress of Mathematicians 1998|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219042054/http://elib.zib.de/ICM98/B/3/3/|archivedate=2015-12-19|df=}}</ref> In 2000-2008 he discovered several new theories including the theory of [[frobenioid]]s, mono-anabelian geometry and the etale theta theory for line bundles over tempered covers of the [[Tate curve]].

On August 30, 2012 Shinichi Mochizuki released four preprints, whose total size was about 500 pages, that develop [[inter-universal Teichmüller theory]] and apply it to attempt to prove several very famous problems in [[Diophantine geometry]].<ref>[http://www.kurims.kyoto-u.ac.jp/~motizuki/Inter-universal%20Teichmuller%20Theory%20IV.pdf Inter-universal Teichmüller theory IV: log-volume computations and set-theoretic foundations], Shinichi Mochizuki, August 2012</ref> These include the strong [[Szpiro conjecture]], the hyperbolic [[Vojta conjecture]] and the [[abc conjecture]] over every number field.  The preprints have not been published.  In September 2018, Mochizuki posted a report on his work by [[Peter Scholze]] and [[Jakob Stix]] asserting that the third preprint contains an irreparable flaw; he also posted several documents containing his rebuttal of their criticism.<ref name="klarreich">
{{cite magazine |url= https://www.quantamagazine.org/titans-of-mathematics-clash-over-epic-proof-of-abc-conjecture-20180920/ |title=Titans of Mathematics Clash Over Epic Proof of ABC Conjecture
 |magazine=[[Quanta Magazine]] |date=September 20, 2018|first=Erica|last=Klarreich|authorlink=Erica Klarreich}}
</ref>  The majority of number theorists have found Mochizuki's preprints very difficult to follow and have not accepted the conjectures as settled, although there are a few prominent exceptions, including Go Yamashita, [[Ivan Fesenko]], and Yuichiro Hoshi, who vouch for the work and have written expositions of the theory.<ref>{{citation|last=Fesenko|first=Ivan|title=Fukugen|authorlink=Ivan Fesenko|journal=Inference: International Review of Science|volume=2|issue=3||url=http://inference-review.com/article/fukugen|year=2016}}</ref><ref>{{citation|last=Roberts|first=David Michael|title=A crisis of identification|journal=Inference: International Review of Science|volume=4|issue=3||url=https://inference-review.com/article/a-crisis-of-identification|year=2019}}</ref>

[[Cole Prize]] (1990) }} {{nihongo|'''Shigefumi Mori'''|森 重文|Mori Shigefumi|extra=born February 23, 1951}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[mathematician]], known for his work in [[algebraic geometry]], particularly in relation to the classification of [[three-fold]]s. ==Career== Mori completed his PhD titled "The Endomorphism Rings of Some Abelian Varieties" under [[Masayoshi Nagata]] at [[Kyoto University]] in 1978.{{MathGenealogy|id=100894}} He was visiting professor at [[Harvard University]] during 1977–1980, the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in 1981–82, [[Columbia University]] 1985–87 and the [[University of Utah]] for periods during 1987–89 and again during 1991–92. He has been a professor at [[Kyoto University]] since 1990. ==Work== He generalized the classical approach to the classification of [[algebraic surfaces]] to the classification of algebraic [[three-folds]]. The classical approach used the concept of [[minimal model (birational geometry)|minimal model]]s of [[algebraic surfaces]]. He found that the concept of [[minimal model (birational geometry)|minimal models]] can be applied to [[three-folds]] as well if we allow some [[Singularity (mathematics)|singularities]] on them. The extension of Mori’s results to dimensions higher than three is called the [[minimal model program]] and is an active area of research in algebraic geometry. He has been elected president of the [[International Mathematical Union]], becoming the first head of the group from East Asia.http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/08/12/national/kyoto-university-professor-elected-head-international-mathematical-union/ ==Awards== He was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1990 at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]]. == Selected publications == * {{cite journal | last = Mori | first = Shigefumi | title = Projective manifolds with ample tangent bundles | journal = [[Ann. of Math.]] | volume = 110 | year = 1979 | pages = 593–606 | doi = 10.2307/1971241 | issue = 3 | jstor = 1971241 | mr = 0554387 }} * {{cite journal | last = Mori | first = Shigefumi | title = Threefolds whose canonical bundles are not numerically effective | journal = [[Ann. of Math.]] | volume = 116 | year = 1982 | pages = 133–176 | doi = 10.2307/2007050 | issue = 1 | jstor = 2007050 | mr = 0662120 | pmc = 349565 }} * {{cite journal | last = Mori | first = Shigefumi | title = Flip theorem and existence of minimal models for 3-folds | journal = [[J. [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Awards|BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] (2012) }} '''David Bryant Mumford''' (born 11 June 1937) is an American [[mathematician]] known for distinguished work in [[algebraic geometry]], and then for research into [[computer vision|vision]] and [[pattern theory]]. He won the [[Fields Medal]] and was a [[MacArthur Fellow]]. In 2010 he was awarded the [[National Medal of Science]]. He is currently a University Professor Emeritus in the Division of Applied Mathematics at [[Brown University]]. ==Early life== Mumford was born in [[Worth, West Sussex]] in [[England]], of an English father and American mother. His father William started an experimental school in [[Tanzania]] and worked for the then newly created [[United Nations]].{{cite book|title=Fields Medallists' Lectures, World Scientific Series in 20th Century Mathematics, Vol 5|date=1997|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-9810231170|page=225|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q6eSjV-0egUC&pg=PA225}} In high school, he was a finalist in the prestigious [[Westinghouse Science Talent Search]]. After attending the [[Phillips Exeter Academy]], Mumford went to Harvard, where he became a student of [[Oscar Zariski]]. At Harvard, he became a [[Putnam Fellow]] in 1955 and 1956. He completed his [[Ph.D.]] in 1961, with a thesis entitled ''Existence of the moduli scheme for curves of any genus''. ==Work in algebraic geometry== Mumford's work in geometry combined traditional geometric insights with the latest algebraic techniques. He published on [[moduli space]]s, with a theory summed up in his book ''[[Geometric Invariant Theory]]'', on the equations defining an [[abelian variety]], and on [[algebraic surface]]s. His books ''Abelian Varieties'' (with [[C. P. Ramanujam]]) and ''Curves on an Algebraic Surface'' combined the old and new theories. His lecture notes on [[scheme theory]] circulated for years in unpublished form, at a time when they were, beside the treatise [[Éléments de géométrie algébrique]], the only accessible introduction. They are now available as ''The Red Book of Varieties and Schemes'' ({{isbn|3-540-63293-X}}). Other work that was less thoroughly written up were lectures on varieties defined by [[quadric]]s, and a study of [[Goro Shimura]]'s papers from the 1960s. Mumford's research did much to revive the classical theory of [[theta function]]s, by showing that its algebraic content was large, and enough to support the main parts of the theory by reference to finite analogues of the [[Heisenberg group]]. This work on the [[equations defining abelian varieties]] appeared in 1966–7. He published some further books of lectures on the theory. He also was one of the founders of the [[Toric geometry|toroidal embedding]] theory; and sought to apply the theory to [[Gröbner basis]] techniques, through students who worked in algebraic computation. ==Work on pathologies in algebraic geometry== In a sequence of four papers published in the ''[[American Journal of Mathematics]]'' between 1961 and 1975, Mumford explored pathological behavior in [[algebraic geometry]], that is, phenomena that would not arise if the world of algebraic geometry were as well-behaved as one might expect from looking at the simplest examples. These pathologies fall into two types: (a) bad behavior in characteristic p and (b) bad behavior in moduli spaces. ===Characteristic-''p'' pathologies=== Mumford's philosophy in characteristic ''p'' was as follows:
A nonsingular characteristic ''p'' variety is analogous to a general non-Kähler complex manifold; in particular, a projective embedding of such a variety is not as strong as a [[Kähler metric]] on a complex manifold, and the Hodge–Lefschetz–Dolbeault theorems on [[sheaf cohomology]] break down in every possible way.
In the first Pathologies paper, Mumford finds an everywhere regular differential form on a smooth projective surface that is not closed, and shows that Hodge symmetry fails for classical [[Enriques surface]]s in characteristic two. This second example is developed further in Mumford's third paper on classification of surfaces in characteristic ''p'' (written in collaboration with [[E. Bombieri]]). This pathology can now be explained in terms of the [[Picard scheme]] of the surface, and in particular, its failure to be a [[reduced scheme]], which is a theme developed in Mumford's book "Lectures on Curves on an Algebraic Surface". Worse pathologies related to p-torsion in [[crystalline cohomology]] were explored by [[Luc Illusie]] (Ann. Sci. Ec. Norm. Sup. (4) 12 (1979), 501–661). In the second Pathologies paper, Mumford gives a simple example of a surface in characteristic ''p'' where the [[geometric genus]] is non-zero, but the second Betti number is equal to the rank of the [[Néron–Severi group]]. Further such examples arise in [[Zariski surface]] theory. He also conjectures that the [[Kodaira vanishing theorem]] is false for surfaces in characteristic ''p''. In the third paper, he gives an example of a [[Normal variety|normal]] surface for which Kodaira vanishing fails. The first example of a smooth surface for which Kodaira vanishing fails was given by [[Michel Raynaud]] in 1978. ===Pathologies of moduli spaces=== In the second Pathologies paper, Mumford finds that the [[Hilbert scheme]] parametrizing space curves of degree 14 and genus 24 has a multiple component. In the fourth Pathologies paper, he finds reduced and irreducible complete curves which are not specializations of non-singular curves. These sorts of pathologies were considered to be fairly scarce when they first appeared. But recently, [[Ravi Vakil]] in a paper called "Murphy's law in algebraic geometry" has shown that Hilbert schemes of nice geometric objects can be arbitrarily "bad", with unlimited numbers of components and with arbitrarily large multiplicities (Invent. Math. 164 (2006), 569–590). ==Classification of surfaces== In three papers written between 1969 and 1976 (the last two in collaboration with [[Enrico Bombieri]]), Mumford extended the [[Enriques–Kodaira classification]] of smooth [[projective surface]]s from the case of the complex [[ground field]] to the case of an [[algebraically closed]] ground field of characteristic ''p''. The final answer turns out to be essentially as the answer in the complex case (though the methods employed are sometimes quite different), once two important adjustments are made. The first is that one may get "non-classical" surfaces, which come about when ''p''-torsion in the [[Picard scheme]] degenerates to a non-reduced group scheme. The second is the possibility of obtaining [[quasi-elliptic surface]]s in characteristics two and three. These are surfaces fibred over a curve where the general fibre is a curve of [[arithmetic genus]] one with a cusp. Once these adjustments are made, the surfaces are divided into four classes by their [[Kodaira dimension]], as in the complex case. The four classes are: a) Kodaira dimension minus infinity. These are the [[ruled surface]]s. b) Kodaira dimension 0. These are the [[K3 surface]]s, [[abelian surface]]s, hyperelliptic and [[quasi-hyperelliptic surface]]s, and [[Enriques surface]]s. There are classical and non-classical examples in the last two Kodaira dimension zero cases. c) Kodaira dimension 1. These are the elliptic and [[quasi-elliptic surface]]s not contained in the last two groups. d) Kodaira dimension 2. These are the [[surfaces of general type]]. ==Awards and honors== [[File:Mumford2.jpg|thumb|220px|David Mumford in 1975]] Mumford was awarded a [[Fields medal|Fields Medal]] in 1974. He was a [[MacArthur Fellow]] from 1987 to 1992. He won the [[Shaw Prize]] in 2006. In 2007 he was awarded the [[Steele Prize]] for Mathematical Exposition by the [[American Mathematical Society]]. In 2008 he was awarded the [[Wolf Prize]]; on receiving the prize in Jerusalem from [[Shimon Peres]], Mumford announced that he was donating half of the prize money to [[Birzeit University]] in the [[Palestinian territories]] and half to [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726104951/http://www.gisha.org/index.php?intLanguage=2&intSiteSN=137&intItemId=107 Gisha], an Israeli organization that promotes the right to freedom of movement of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.{{cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/1.4984908|title=U.S. prof. gives Israeli prize money to Palestinian university – Haaretz – Israel News|publisher=[[Haaretz]]|date=2008-05-26 |accessdate=2008-05-26|last=|first=}}{{cite journal|last=Mumford|first=David|title=The Wolf Prize and Supporting Palestinian Education|journal=Notices of the American Mathematical Society|date=September 2008|volume=55|issue=8|pages=919|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200808/200808-full-issue.pdf|publisher=American Mathematical Society|issn=0002-9920}} In 2010 he was awarded the [[National Medal of Science]].{{cite web|url=https://news.brown.edu/pressreleases/2010/10/mumford|title=Mathematician David Mumford to receive National Medal of Science|publisher=[[Brown University]]|date=2010-10-15|accessdate=2010-10-25|last=|first=}} In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-02-10. There is a long list of awards and honors besides the above, including *[[Intel Science Talent Search|Westinghouse Science Talent Search]] finalist, 1953. *[[Harvard Society of Fellows|Junior Fellow]] at Harvard from 1958 to 1961. *Elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] in 1975. *Honorary Fellow from [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] in 1978. *Honorary D. Sc. from the [[University of Warwick]] in 1983. *Foreign Member of [[Accademia dei Lincei|Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]], [[Rome]], in 1991. *Honorary Member of [[London Mathematical Society]] in 1995. *Elected to the [[American Philosophical Society]] in 1997. *Honorary D. Sc. from [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]] in 2000.[https://www.ntnu.edu/phd/honorary-doctors NTNU's list of honorary doctors] *Honorary D. Sc. from [[Rockefeller University]] in 2001. *[[Longuet-Higgins Prize]] in 2005 and 2009. *Foreign Member of [[The Royal Society]] in 2008. *Foreign Member of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dnva.no/c26849/artikkel/vis.html?tid=40116 |title=Gruppe 1: Matematiske fag |publisher=[[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110152102/http://www.dnva.no/c26849/artikkel/vis.html?tid=40116 |archivedate=10 November 2013 |df= }} *Honorary Doctorate from [[Brown University]] in 2011.http://www.browndailyherald.com/commencement-2011-honorary-degrees-1.2579444 *2012 [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Awards|BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] in the Basic Sciences category (jointly with Ingrid Daubechies). * Honoris Causa University of Hyderabad, India 2012 He was elected President of the [[International Mathematical Union]] in 1995 and served from 1995 to 1999. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=25em}} *[[Castelnuovo–Mumford regularity]] *[[Mumford's compactness theorem]] *[[Haboush's theorem]] *[[Hilbert–Mumford criterion]] *[[Mapping class group#Stable mapping class group|Stable mapping class group]] *[[Mumford measure]] *[[Mumford vanishing theorem]] *[[Theta representation]] *[[Arithmetic of abelian varieties#Manin–Mumford conjecture|Manin–Mumford conjecture]] *[[Horrocks–Mumford bundle]] *[[Deligne–Mumford moduli space of stable curves]] *[[Algebraic stack]] *[[Moduli scheme]] *[[Prym variety|Prym varieties]] *[[Stable map#The stable map compactification|Stable maps]] *[[Mumford–Shah functional|Mumford–Shah energy functional]] {{div col end}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Publications== * ''Lectures on Curves on Algebraic Surfaces'' (with George Bergman), [[Princeton University Press]], 1964. * ''Geometric Invariant Theory'', Springer-Verlag, 1965 – 2nd edition, with J. pages.title: Mircea Mustață
pages.text:
'''Mircea Immanuel Mustață''' (born 1971 in [[Romania]]) is a Romanian mathematician, specializing in [[algebraic geometry]].

Mustață received from the [[University of Bucharest]] a bachelor's degree in 1995 and a master's degree in 1996<ref name=CV/> and from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] a [[Ph.D.]] in 2001 with thesis advisor [[David Eisenbud]] and thesis ''Singularities and Jet Schemes''.<ref name=mathgen>{{MathGenealogy|id=56789}}</ref> As a postdoc he was at the [[University of Nice Sophia Antipolis]] (Fall 2001), at the [[Isaac Newton Institute]] (Spring 2002), and at [[Harvard University]] (2002–2004); he was from 2001 to 2004 a [[Clay Mathematics Institute|Clay Research Fellow]]. At the [[University of Michigan]] in [[Ann Arbor]] he became in 2004 an associate professor and in 2008 a full professor.<ref name=CV>{{cite web|title=Mircea Mustaţă, C.V.|website=umich.edu|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~mmustata/cv2010_03_31.pdf}}</ref>

In fall 2006, he was at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mircea Mustata|website=IAS|url=http://www.ias.edu/scholars/mircea-mustata}}</ref> From 2006 to 2011 he held a five-year Packard Fellowship.<ref name=CV/>

Mustață was an invited speaker at the [[European Mathematical Congress]] in 2004 Stockholm and at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 2014 in Seoul.<ref>{{cite arxiv|title=The dimension of jet schemes of singular varieties|year=2014|eprint=1404.7731|last1=Mustata|first1=Mircea|class=math.AG}}</ref>

His research deals with a wide range of topics in algebraic geometry, including:
{{blockquote|various invariants of singularities of algebraic varieties, such as minimal log discrepancies, log canonical thresholds, [[multiplier ideal]]s, [[Bernstein–Sato polynomial]]s and F-thresholds ... resolutions of singularities, jet schemes, [[D-module]]s or positive characteristic methods ... [[birational geometry]], asymptotic base loci and invariants of divisors, and [[Toric variety|toric varieties]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mircea Mustaţă (homepage)|website=umich.edu|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~mmustata/}}</ref>}}

Mustață's doctoral students include [[June Huh]].<ref name=mathgen/>

[[V. K. Patodi]] }} '''Mudumbai Seshachalu Narasimhan''' {{small|[[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]}} (born 1932) is an [[India]]n [[mathematician]]. He is known, along with [[C. S. Seshadri]], for their proof of the [[Narasimhan–Seshadri theorem]], and both were elected as [[Fellow of the Royal Society|Fellows of the Royal Society]]. He has been the only Indian to receive the [[King Faisal International Prize]] in the field of science. ==Education== Narasimhan did his undergraduate studies at [[Loyola College, Chennai]], where he was taught by Fr Racine. [[Fr Racine]] had studied with the famous French mathematicians [[Élie Cartan]] and [[Jacques Hadamard]], and connected his students with the latest developments in modern mathematics. Among Racine's other students who achieved eminence are [[Subbaramiah Minakshisundaram]], [[K. G. Ramanathan]], [[C S Seshadri]], [[Raghavan Narasimhan]], and [[C. P. Ramanujam]].{{cn|date=April 2018}} Narasimhan went to the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] (TIFR), [[Bombay]], for his graduate studies. He obtained his Ph.D. from [[University of Mumbai]] in 1960; his advisor was [[K. S. Chandrasekharan]].{{cn|date=April 2018}} ==Career== ===Degrees and posts held=== * Visiting Scholar, [[Institute for Advanced Study]] (1968-1969){{cite web |url = http://www.ias.edu/people/cos/users/mnarasimha01 |title = Community of Scholars Profile: Narasimhan, Mudumbai S. |publisher = ''[[Institute for Advanced Study]]'' |accessdate = 27 September 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130107174137/http://www.ias.edu/people/cos/users/mnarasimha01 |archivedate = 7 January 2013 |df = dmy-all }} * Fellow of the Royal Society, London * Head, Mathematics Group of the Abdus Salam International Centre for Theoretical Physics (1992–1999) * Honorary Fellow, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Bangalore Centre. ===Awards and felicitations=== * [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize]] (1975) * [[TWAS Prize]] for Mathematics (1987){{Cite web |url=http://twas.org/opportunities/prizes-and-awards |title=Prizes and Awards |date=2016 |publisher=The World Academy of Sciences}} * [[Padma Bhushan]] (1990){{cite web|url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf |title=Padma Awards |publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India |date=2015 |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6U68ulwpb?url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf |archivedate=15 November 2014 |df= }} * [[King Faisal International Prize for Science]], 2006 (jointly with [[Simon Donaldson]], Imperial College)*[http://www.ams.org/notices/200603/comm-faisal.pdf Donaldson and Narasimhan Receive 2006 King Faisal Prize] - Notices of the AMS, March 2006, Volume 53, Number 3. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{Citation | last1=Narasimhan | first1=M. '''Max Noether''' (24 September 1844 – 13 December 1921) was a [[German people|German]] [[mathematician]] who worked on [[algebraic geometry]] and the theory of [[algebraic functions]]. He has been called "one of the finest mathematicians of the nineteenth century".<ref>Lederman, p. 69.</ref> He was the father of [[Emmy Noether]].

==Biography==
Max Noether was born in [[Mannheim]] in 1844, to a [[Jewish family]] of wealthy wholesale hardware dealers. His grandfather, Elias Samuel, had started the business in [[Bruchsal]] in 1797. In 1809 the [[Grand Duchy of Baden]] established a "Tolerance Edict", which assigned a hereditary surname to the male head of every Jewish family which did not already possess one. Thus the Samuels became the Noether family, and as part of this Christianization of names, their son Hertz (Max's father) became Hermann. Max was the third of five children Hermann had with his wife Amalia Würzburger.<ref>Dick, pp. 4–7.</ref>

At 14, Max contracted [[polio]] and was afflicted by its effects for the rest of his life. Through [[autodidacticism|self-study]], he learned advanced mathematics and entered the [[University of Heidelberg]] in 1865. He served on the faculty there for several years, then moved to the [[University of Erlangen]] in 1888. While there, he helped to found the field of [[algebraic geometry]].<ref name="Led6971">Lederman, pp. 69–71.</ref>

In 1880 he married Ida Amalia Kaufmann, the daughter of another wealthy Jewish merchant family. Two years later they had their first child, named Amalia ("Emmy") after her mother. [[Emmy Noether]] went on to become a central figure in [[abstract algebra]]. In 1883 they had a son named Alfred, who later studied [[chemistry]] before dying in 1918. Their third child, Fritz, was born in 1884. Like Emmy, [[Fritz Noether]] also found prominence as a mathematician. Little is known about their fourth child, Gustav Robert, born in 1889. He suffered from continual illness and died in 1928.<ref>Dick, pp. 9–45.</ref>

Max Noether served as an ''Ordinarius'' (full professor) at Erlangen for many years, and died there on 13 December 1921.

==Work on algebraic geometry==

[[Alexander von Brill|Brill]] and Max Noether developed alternative proofs using algebraic methods for much of [[Bernhard Riemann|Riemann]]'s work on [[Riemann surface]]s. [[Brill–Noether theory]] went further by estimating the dimension of the space of maps of given degree ''d'' from an [[algebraic curve]] to [[projective space]] '''P'''<sup>''n''</sup>. In [[birational geometry]], Noether introduced the fundamental technique of [[blowing up]] in order to prove [[resolution of singularities]] for plane curves.

Max Noether made major contributions to the theory of [[algebraic surface]]s. [[Noether's formula]] is the first case of the Riemann-Roch theorem for surfaces. The [[Noether inequality]] is one of the main restrictions on the possible discrete invariants of a surface. The Noether-Lefschetz theorem (proved by [[Solomon Lefschetz|Lefschetz]]) says that the [[Picard group]] of a very general surface of degree at least 4 in '''P'''<sup>3</sup> is generated by the restriction of the [[line bundle]] ''O''(1).

Max Noether and [[Guido Castelnuovo|Castelnuovo]] showed that the [[Cremona group]] of birational automorphisms of the complex projective plane is generated by the "quadratic transformation"

: [''x'',''y'',''z''] ↦ [1/''x'', 1/''y'', 1/''z'']

together with the group ''PGL''(3,'''C''') of automorphisms of '''P'''<sup>2</sup>. Even today, no explicit generators are known for the group of birational automorphisms of '''P'''<sup>3</sup>.

{{Nihongo|'''Tadao Oda'''|小田忠雄|Oda Tadao}} (born 1940, [[Kyoto]]) is a Japanese [[mathematician]] working in the field of [[algebraic geometry]], especially [[toric variety|toric varieties]].  The field of toric varieties was developed by [[Michel Demazure|Demazure]], [[David Mumford|Mumford]], Miyake, Oda and others in the 1970s. He is also known for a book on toric varieties: ''Convex Bodies and Algebraic Geometry: An Introduction to the Theory of Toric Varieties.''<ref>{{cite journal|author=Reid, Miles|authorlink=Miles Reid|title=Review: ''Convex bodies and algebraic geometry: An introduction to toric varieties'' by Tadao Oda|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|year=1989|volume=21|pages=360–364|doi=10.1090/S0273-0979-1989-15864-3}}</ref>

In 1958 Oda graduated from [[Tokai High School]] in [[Nagoya]], Japan, where [[Shigefumi Mori]] and Hisasi Morikawa also graduated from. He earned his bachelor's degree from [[Kyoto University]] in 1962, and five years later earned a Ph.D. under David Mumford from [[Harvard University]] with thesis ''Abelian varieties over a perfect field and Dieudonné Modules''.<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=28506}}</ref> After completing his Ph.D., Oda was an associate professor at [[Nagoya University]] and became a professor at [[Tohoku University]] in 1975. He remained at the university for 28 years. He is an emeritus professor at [[Tohoku University]]. Oda wrote "Algebraic Geometry, Sendai, 1985" with Hisasi Morikawa, a former professor at [[Nagoya University]].

Tadao has belonged to the [[Kiwanis Club]] of Sendai since 1999 and was elected to a three-year term as a trustee of Kiwanis International in 2008.<ref>[http://www.kiwanisone.org/Pages/Resources/default.aspx?PageID=356 Tadao Oda, Kiwanis International Trustee]</ref>

[[File:Arthur Ogus.jpg|thumb|Arthur Ogus in 1975]]
'''Arthur Edward Ogus''' is an American [[mathematician]]. His research is in [[algebraic geometry]]; he has served as chair of the mathematics department at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref name="profile"/>

Ogus did his undergraduate studies at [[Reed College]], graduating in 1968, and earned his doctorate in 1972 from [[Harvard University]] under the supervision of [[Robin Hartshorne]]. His doctoral students at Berkeley include [[Kai Behrend]].<ref name="profile">[http://math.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/arthur-e-ogus Faculty profile], UC Berkeley, retrieved 2014-11-19.</ref><ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=23500}}</ref>

In September 2015, a conference in honor of his 70th birthday was held at the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]] in France.<ref>[http://www.ihes.fr/~abbes/Ogus/ogus70.html Algebraic geometry: A conference in honor of Arthur Ogus on the occasion of his 70th birthday], [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]], retrieved 2014-11-19.</ref>

'''Olga Arsenievna Oleinik''' [[HFRSE]] ({{lang-ru|link=no|О́льга Арсе́ньевна Оле́йник}}) (2 July 1925 – 13 October 2001) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[mathematician]] who conducted pioneering work on the theory of [[partial differential equation]]s, the theory of strongly inhomogeneous elastic media, and the mathematical theory of [[boundary layer]]s. She was a student of [[Ivan Petrovsky]].  She studied and worked at the [[Moscow State University]].

She received many prizes for her remarkable contributions: the [[Chebotarev Prize]] in 1952; the State Prize 1988; the [[Petrowsky Prize]] in 1995; and the Prize of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] in 1995. Also she was member of several foreign academies of sciences, and earned several honorary degrees.

== Life ==

On May 2, 1985 Olga Oleinik was awarded the [[laurea]] [[honoris causa]] by the [[Sapienza University of Rome]], jointly with [[Fritz John]].<ref>See {{harv|Vernacchia-Galli|1986|pp=845–855}}.</ref>

== Work ==

=== Research activity ===
She authored more than 370 mathematical publications and 8 monographs, as the sole author or in collaboration with others: her work covers [[algebraic geometry]], the theory of [[partial differential equation]]s where her work enlightened various aspects, [[elasticity theory]] and [[boundary layer]]s theory.

=== Teaching activity ===
She was an enthusiast and very active teacher, advising the [[thesis]] of 57 "[[Candidate of Sciences|candidates]]".

Frans Oort
pages.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Frans Oort | image = Frans Oort.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Frans Oort, Oberwolfach 2004 | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1935|7|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bussum]], [[Netherlands]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = | alma_mater = [[University of Leiden]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisors = {{ill|Willem Titus van Est|de}}
{{ill|Jacob Murre|de}} | doctoral_students = | known_for = [[André–Oort conjecture]] | awards = }} '''Frans Oort''' (born 17 July 1935) is a Dutch mathematician, specializing in [[algebraic geometry]]. ==Biography== Oort studied from 1952 to 1958 at [[Leiden University]], where he graduated with a thesis on [[elliptic curve]]s. He received his doctorate in 1961 in Leiden from {{ill|Willem Titus van Est|de}} and {{ill|Jacob Murre|de}} with thesis ''Reducible and Multiple Algebraic Curves'',{{MathGenealogy|id=26911}} but had previously studied under [[Jean-Pierre Serre]] in [[Paris]] and [[Aldo Andreotti]] in [[Pisa]]. Oort was from 1961 at the [[University of Amsterdam]], where he became a professor in 1967. In 1977, until his retirement in 2000, he was a professor at [[Utrecht University]].{{cite web|title=Frans Oort|website=Academia Europaea|url=http://www.ae-info.org/ae/Member/Oort_Frans}} He was a visiting scholar at several academic institutions, including [[Harvard University]] (1966/67) and [[Aarhus University]] (1972/73). In 2008 he was the Eilenberg Professor at [[Columbia University]]. His research deals with, among other topics, [[Abelian variety|abelian varieties]] and their [[Module (mathematics)|modules]]. In 1994 he formulated what is now known as the [[André–Oort conjecture]] (generalizing a conjecture made in 1989 by [[Yves André]]).{{cite book|author=Zannier, Umberto|authorlink=Umberto Zannier|title=Some problems of unlikely intersections in arithmetic and geometry|year=2012|publisher=Princeton University Press|page=9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S-bYWbSDHLIC&pg=PA9|isbn=9780691153711}} In 2000 Oort proved a conjecture made by Grothendieck in 1970.{{Cite journal|author=Oort, Frans|title=Newton polygons and formal groups: Conjectures by Manin and Grothendieck|journal=Ann. of Math. |series=Series 2 |volume=152 |issue=1|pages=183–206|year=2000|arxiv=math/0007201}} Oort was a co-author of an article on [[Poncelet's closure theorem]]{{cite book|author=Bos, Henk JM|authorlink=Henk J. M. Bos|author2=Kers, Cees|author3=Oort, Frans|title=Poncelet's closure theorem, its history, its modern formulation, a comparison of its modern proof with those by Poncelet and Jacobi, and some mathematical remarks inspired by these early proofs|publisher=Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht. Mathematics Instituut|year=1984}} and the author of ''An aspect of harmony in music of Johann Sebastian Bach''. In 1962 Oort was an Invited Speaker with talk ''Multiple algebraic curves'' at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Stockholm]]. In 2011 he was elected a member of [[Academia Europaea]]. In July 2013 he gave a talk at the [[International Congress of Chinese Mathematicians]] in [[Tapei]].{{cite journal|author=Oort, Frans|title=Prime numbers|journal=Notices of the International Congress of Chinese Mathematicians|volume= 1|issue=2|pages=60–78|date=November 2013|url=https://www.intlpress.com/site/pub/files/_fulltext/journals/iccm/2013/0001/0002/ICCM-2013-0001-0002-a008.pdf}} His doctoral students include [[Michiel Hazewinkel]], [[Aise Johan de Jong]], [[Hendrik Lenstra]] and [[Joseph Steenbrink]]. He was married to (and is now divorced from) author {{ill|Marijke Harberts|nl}}, who wrote ''Afschied van Joke Smit'' (1987 biography of [[Joke Smit]]), ''Doezamand: Roman'' (1994 novel based upon her life as a student), and ''Eerlijk gezegd: Interviews met vrouwen'' (1974 collection of interviews with women); the couple have three grown sons, among whom is the [[Ultimate Frisbee]] player Jeroen Oort. ==Selected publications== * ''Commutative group schemes'', Springer 1966; {{cite book|title=pbk reprint|year=2006|url=https://books.google.com/?id=czDtCAAAQBAJ|isbn=9783540371717|last1=Oort|first1=F}} * as editor: ''Algebraic Geometry'', Oslo 1970, Wolters-Noordhoff 1972 * with Ke-Zheng Li: [https://books.google.com/books?id=NAwU_M_6UKAC ''Moduli of supersingular abelian varieties''], Springer 1998 * as editor with Steenbrink and van der Geer: '' Arithmetic algebraic geometry '', Birkhäuser 1991; {{cite book|title=pbk reprint 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUHhBwAAQBAJ|isbn=9781461204572|last1=g|first1=van der Geer|last2=Oort|first2=F|last3=Steenbrink|first3=J.H.M|date=2012-12-06}} * as editor with Carel Faber and Gerard van der Geer: [https://books.google.com/books?id=DfQW3YHLGIEC ''Moduli of abelian varieties''], Birkhäuser 2001 * {{cite book|chapter=''Did earlier thoughts inspire Grothendieck?'' by Frans Oort|title=''In:'' Alexander Grothendieck: A mathematical portrait|editor=L. Schneps|publisher=International Press|location=Sommerville, Massachusetts|year=2014|pages=231–268|chapter-url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/7764/b81a09dbd3d00338af87fce23b92e8c84260.pdf}} * with Ching-Li Chai: {{cite journal|title=Life and work of Alexander Grothendieck|journal=ICCM Notices|volume=5|year=2017|pages=22–50|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/679f/8491a0db3f7f0f8202dae0baf116b8117e24.pdf}} ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.math.uu.nl/people/oort/ Homepage in Utrecht] * {{cite web|title=Frans Oort on "John Tate receives the 2010 Abel Prize"|date=23 January 2016|website=YouTube|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MVQnmfZsZv4}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oort, Frans}} [[Category:20th-century Dutch mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century Dutch mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Leiden University alumni]] [[Category:University of Amsterdam faculty]] [[Category:Utrecht University faculty]] [[Category:Members of Academia Europaea]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

pages.title: Donal O'Shea
pages.text:
[[File:DonalOShea-2008.jpg|thumb|Donal O'Shea]]
'''Donal O'Shea''' is a Canadian [[mathematician]], who is also noted for his bestselling books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanscientist.org/bookshelf/pub/scientists-nightstand-donal-oshea |title=Scientists' Nightstand: Donal O'Shea |publisher=[[American Scientist]] |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2016-11-14}}</ref> He is currently the fifth president of [[New College of Florida]] in [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]], a position to which he was named on July 1, 2012. Before coming to New College, he served in various roles at [[Mount Holyoke College]], including professor of mathematics, dean of faculty, and vice president for academic affairs.<ref name="heraldtribune1">{{cite web|author=Christopher O'Donnell |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20120415/mathematician-deemed-perfect-fit-as-next-new-college-president |title=Mathematician deemed perfect fit as next New College president – News – Sarasota Herald-Tribune – Sarasota, FL |website=Heraldtribune.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-14}}</ref><ref name=":0" />  

O'Shea graduated with a [[B.Sc.]] from [[Harvard College]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ncf.edu/directory/listing/donal-oshea/|title=Directory {{!}} Donal O’Shea|last=|first=|date=2015-12-31|work=New College of Florida Directory|access-date=2018-03-15|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>, and received a [[Ph.D.]] in mathematics from [[Queen's University]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]] in 1981; his thesis, titled ''On μ-Equivalent Families of Singularities'', was written under the direction of Albert John Coleman.

==Bibliography==
Some of his best known books are:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/83902.Donal_O_Shea |title=Donal O'Shea (Author of The Poincaré Conjecture) |website=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-14}}</ref>
* ''The Poincaré Conjecture: In Search of the Shape of the Universe'' <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Donal-OShea/e/B001ITRLMM |title=Donal O'Shea: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle |website=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-14}}</ref>

The book has consistently received good reviews.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ian Pindar |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2008/nov/29/poincare-conjecture-donal-o-shea |title=Review: The Poincaré Conjecture by Donal O'Shea | Books |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200801/tx080100037p.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Poincaré Conjecture and Poincaré’s Prize : Review |website=Ams.org |accessdate=2016-11-14}}
</ref>
* [[David A. Cox]], John Little, and Donal O'Shea: ''Using algebraic geometry'', Graduate Texts in Mathematics, vol. 185, Springer-Verlag, 2005. 
* [[David A. Cox]], John Little, and Donal O'Shea: ''Ideals, varieties, and algorithms: an introduction to computational algebraic geometry and commutative algebra'', 3rd. edition, Springer Verlag, 2007.

[[Infosys Prize]] (2013) }} '''Rahul Pandharipande''' (born 1969) is a [[mathematician]] who is currently a professor of mathematics at the [[ETH Zurich|Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zürich]] (ETH) working in [[algebraic geometry]]. His particular interests concern [[moduli space]]s, enumerative invariants associated to moduli spaces, such as [[Gromov–Witten invariants]] and [[Donaldson–Thomas theory|Donaldson–Thomas invariants]], and the cohomology of the moduli space of curves.{{cite web | url=http://www.claymath.org/people/rahul-pandharipande | title=Rahul Pandharipande | publisher=Clay Mathematics Institute | accessdate=14 March 2018 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.infosys-science-foundation.com/prize/laureates/2013/rahul-pandharipande.asp | title=Infosys Prize - Laureates - Mathematical Sciences, 2013 Prof. Rahul Pandharipande | publisher=Infosys Science Foundation |accessdate=14 March 2018 }} His father [[Vijay Raghunath Pandharipande]] was a renowned theoretical physicist who worked in the area of nuclear physics. == Educational and professional history == {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2019}} He received his [[A.B.]] from [[Princeton University]] in 1990 and his [[Ph.D.]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1994 with a thesis entitled `''A Compactification over the Moduli Space of Stable Curves of the Universal Moduli Space of Slope-Semistable Vector Bundles'''. His thesis advisor at Harvard was [[Joe Harris (mathematician)|Joe Harris]]. After teaching at the [[University of Chicago]] and the [[California Institute of Technology]], he joined the faculty as Professor of Mathematics at [[Princeton University]] in 2002. In 2011, he accepted a Professorship at [[ETH Zürich]]. == Selected Publications[https://people.math.ethz.ch/~rahul/cv.pdf CV]== *[[William Fulton (mathematician)|William Fulton]] and Rahul Pandharipande, Notes on stable maps and quantum cohomology, in Proceedings of Algebraic Geometry – Santa Cruz (1995), Proc. Sympos. Pure Math. 62, 45–96. (One of the standard sources on Gromov–Witten theory.) *Tom Graber and Rahul Pandharipande, Localization of virtual classes, [[Inventiones Mathematicae]] '''135''' (1999), no. 2, 487–518. (This introduced a [[Localization formula for equivariant cohomology|Atiyah-Bott type localisation formula]] for the virtual fundamental class.) *Carel Faber and Rahul Pandharipande, Hodge integrals and Gromov–Witten theory, [[Inventiones Mathematicae]] '''139''' (2000), no. 1, 173–199. *[[Andrei Okounkov]] and Rahul Pandharipande, Gromov–Witten theory, Hurwitz numbers, and completed cycles, [[Annals of Mathematics]] '''163''' (2006), 517–560. *Andrei Okounkov and Rahul Pandharipande, The equivariant Gromov-Witten theory of \mathbb{P}^1, [[Annals of Mathematics]] '''163''' (2006), 561–605. *Davesh Maulik, [[Nikita Nekrasov]], Andrei Okounkov, and Rahul Pandharipande, Gromov-Witten theory and Donaldson-Thomas theory I, [[Compositio Mathematica]] '''142''' (2006), 1263–1285. (In this paper a change of variables is introduced to relate Gromov–Witten theory to Donaldson–Thomas theory. This work was explicitly mentioned in the citations for his 2013 [[Infosys Prize]] and 2013 [[Clay Research Award]].) *Rahul Pandharipande and [[Richard Thomas (mathematician)|Richard P. '''Aleksei Nikolaevich Parshin''', sometimes romanized as '''Alexey Nikolaevich Paršin''', ({{lang-ru|Алексей Николаевич Паршин}}; born 7 November 1942 in [[Yekaterinburg|Sverdlovsk]]) is a Russian mathematician, specializing in [[number theory]] and [[algebraic geometry]].

==Education and career==
Parshin graduated in 1964 from the Faculty of Mathematics and Mechanics of [[Moscow State University]] and then enrolled as a graduate student at the [[Steklov Institute of Mathematics]], where he received his [[Candidate of Sciences|Kand. Nauk]] (Ph.D.) in 1968 under [[Igor Shafarevich]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paršin |first=A. N. |title=Algebraic curves over function fields. |lang=Russian |journal=Dokl. Akad. Nauk SSSR |volume=183 |year=1968 |pages=524–526}}</ref> In 1983 he received his Russian doctorate of sciences ([[Doctor Nauk]]) from Moscow State University. He is now a professor at the Steklov Institute in Moscow, where he is the head of the Department of Algebra, and he is also a professor at Moscow State University.

Parshin proved in 1968 that the [[Mordell conjecture]] is a logical consequence of [[Faltings's theorem#Consequences|Shafarevich's finiteness conjecture]] concerning isomorphism classes of [[abelian variety|abelian varieties]]. In 1983 [[Gerd Faltings]] proved Shafarevich's finiteness conjecture (and thereby the Mordell conjecture).

Shafarevich proved his conjecture for the case with genus ''g'' = 1. In 1968 Parshin proved a special case (for {{math|''S''}} = the empty set) of the following theorem: If {{math|''B''}} is a smooth complex curve and {{math|''S''}} is a finite subset of {{math|''B''}} then there exist only finitely many families (up to isomorphism) of smooth curves of fixed genus ''g'' ≥ 2 over {{math|''B'' \ ''S''}}.<ref name=CaporasoRef>{{cite arxiv|eprint=math/0004078|title=Remarks about uniform boundedness of rational points over function fields|last=Caporaso|first=Lucia|authorlink=Lucia Caporaso |year=2000}}</ref> The general case (for non-empty {{math|''S''}}) of the preceding theorem was proved by [[Suren Arakelov|Arakelov]].<ref name=CaporasoRef/><ref>{{cite arxiv|eprint=math/0311085 |author=Heier, Gordon|title=Uniformly effective Shafarevich conjecture on families of hyperbolic curves over a curve with prescribed degeneracy condition |year=2003}}</ref> At the same time, Parshin gave a new proof (without an application of the Shafarevich finiteness condition) of the Mordell conjecture in function fields (already proved by [[Yuri Manin]] in 1963 and by [[Hans Grauert]] in 1965).<ref>Parshin, [http://www.mathnet.ru/php/archive.phtml?wshow=paper&jrnid=im&paperid=2513&option_lang=eng Algebraic curves over function fields. I], Math. USSR Izvestiya Vol. 2, 1968</ref> Parshin presented his results in his talk ''Quelques conjectures de finitude en géométrie diophantienne''as an invited speaker at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians|ICM]] in 1970 in Nice.<ref>Paršin, A. N. [http://www.mathunion.org/ICM/ICM1970.1/Main/icm1970.1.0467.0472.ocr.pdf "Quelques conjectures de finitude en géométrie Diophantienne."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924235505/http://www.mathunion.org/ICM/ICM1970.1/Main/icm1970.1.0467.0472.ocr.pdf |date=2016-09-24 }} In Actes, Congrès intern. math, Tome 1, vol. 1, pp. 467–471. 1970.</ref>

Parshin's research deals with generalizations of [[class field theory]] in higher dimensions, with integrable systems, and with the history of mathematics. He was an editor for the Russian edition of the collected works of [[David Hilbert]] and was a co-editor, with [[Vladimir Arnold|V. I. Arnold]], of selected works of [[Hermann Weyl]].

Parshin is a corresponding member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]. At the ICM in 2010 he was a Plenary Speaker with his talk titled ''Representations of higher adelic groups and arithmetic''.<ref>Parshin, A. N. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=GFE1vx2pynMC&pg=PA362 "Representations of higher adelic groups and arithmetic."] In Proceedings of the International Congress of Mathematicians, vol. 1, pp. 362–392. 2011.</ref>

==Awards and honors==
* 1996 – [[Humboldt Prize]]
* 2004 – [[Named prizes and medals of the Russian Academy of Sciences#Mathematics|Vinogradov Prize]]
* 2012 – [[Named prizes and medals of the Russian Academy of Sciences#Mathematics|Chebyshev Gold Medal]]
* 2013 – Honorary doctorate from University of Paris XIII

==Selected publications==
* A. N. Parshin: "Путь. Математика и другие миры" (The Way. Mathematics and Other Worlds) Moscow 2002. (Parshin's writings on Russian science and philosophy)
* With Shafarevich, Parshin edited several volumes in the series "Algebraic Geometry and Number Theory" in the Encyclopedia of mathematical sciences published by Springer Verlag.
* with Shafarevich: ''The arithmetic of algebraic varieties''. Proc. Steklov Institute Math., 1986, No. 3.
* with Yuri Zarin: Finiteness problems in algebraic geometry, in ''Eight papers translated from the Russian''. American Mathematical Society Translations Ser. 2, Vol.143, 1989, pp. 35–102, revised version of the original published as an appendix in the Russian edition of [[Serge Lang]] ''Fundamentals of Diophantine Geometry'' (English version of the appendix [http://de.arxiv.org/abs/0912.4325 Online])
*Parshin [https://arxiv.org/abs/0912.3785 ''Numbers as functions. The development of an idea in the Moscow school of algebraic geometry''], in Bolibruch, Osipov, Sinai (eds.) ''Mathematical Events of the Twentieth Century'', Springer 2006, pp. 297–330
*Parshin [http://page.math.tu-berlin.de/~mdmv/archive/18/mdmv-18-1-043.pdf ''Mathematik in Moskau – es war eine große Epoche''], Mitteilungen DMV, Vol. 18, 2010, pp. 43–48

pages.text:
'''Ragni Piene''' (born 18 January 1947, [[Oslo]])<ref>[http://folk.uio.no/ragnip/RPieneCV_11.pdf CV] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910082538/http://folk.uio.no/ragnip/RPieneCV_11.pdf |date=2012-09-10 }}</ref> is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[mathematician]], specializing in [[algebraic geometry]], with particular interest in enumerative results and intersection theory.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mn.uio.no/math/english/people/aca/ragnip/rpienecv_2017.pdf|title=Curriculum vitae|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref>

==Education and career==
Piene received her doctorate in mathematics from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in 1976, advised by [[Steven Kleiman]]. Her dissertation was titled ''Plücker Formulas''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.genealogy.ams.org/id.php?id=35972|title=Ragni Piene - The Mathematics Genealogy Project|website=www.genealogy.ams.org|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref>

She was appointed professor at the [[University of Oslo]] in 1987.<ref name="snl">{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Ragni Piene|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://snl.no/Ragni_Piene|language=Norwegian|accessdate=29 October 2009}}</ref>

==Recognition==
She was elected a member of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] in 1994,<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnva.no/c26848/artikkel/vis.html?tid=27624|title=Gruppe 1: Matematiske fag
|publisher=[[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]]|language=Norwegian|accessdate=29 October 2009}}</ref>
and in 2012 she became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-05-05.</ref>

==Service==
Since 2003 she has been a member of the executive committee of the [[International Mathematical Union]], and was the chair of the [[Abel Prize|Abel Committee]] from 2010/2011 to 2013/2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abelprize.no/c53678/artikkel/vis.html?tid=56493|title=The Abel Committee 2010/2011|accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abelprize.no/c53678/artikkel/vis.html?tid=61675|title=The Abel Committee 2013/2014|accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref>

pages.title: Vincent Pilloni
pages.text:
'''Vincent Pilloni''' (born 1982) is a French mathematician, specializing in [[arithmetic]] algebraic geometry and the [[Langlands program]].

Pilloni studied at the [[École normale supérieure (Paris)|École Normale Supérieure]] and received his doctorate in 2009 from  [[Paris 13 University|Paris 13 University]] with thesis advisor Jacques Tilouine and thesis ''Arithmétique des variétés de Siegel''.<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=144732}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=''Arithmétique des variétés de Siegel'' par Vincent Pilloni|website=theses.fr|url=http://www.theses.fr/2009PA132011}}</ref>

His research deals with, among other topics, the question of how the [[modularity theorem]] for [[elliptic curve]]s over the rational numbers (which led to the proof of [[Fermat's Last Theorem]]) can be extended to [[Abelian variety|abelian varieties]]. With [[Fabrizio Andreatta]] and [[Adrian Iovita]], he made significant progress on general modularity conjectures (following [[Fontaine–Mazur conjecture|Fontaine-Mazur]], [[Robert Langlands|Langlands]], [[Laurent Clozel|Clozel]], and others).

Pilloni is a [[Academic ranks in France|''Chargé de recherche'']] of [[CNRS]] at the [[École normale supérieure de Lyon]] (UMPA).

In 2018 he was an invited speaker, with Fabrizio Andreatta and Adrian Iovita, at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in Rio de Janeiro.<ref>{{cite book|author=Andreatta, Fabrizio|author2=Iovita, Adrian|author3=Pilloni, Vincent|chapter=p-adic variation of automorphic sheaves|title=Proc. Int. Long. of Math. – 2018 Rio de Janeiro|volume=vol. 1|pages=291–318|chapter-url=http://perso.ens-lyon.fr/vincent.pilloni/ICM.pdf}}</ref> In 2018 Pilloni received the Prix Élie Cartan.

==Selected publications==
* Sur la théorie de Hida, Bull. Soc. Math. France, vol. 140, 2012, pp. 335–400.
* Modularité, formes de Siegel et surfaces abéliennes, J. Reine Angew. Math., Vol. 666, 2012, pp. 35–82.
* Prolongement analytique sur les variétés de Siegel, Duke Math. J., Vol. 157, 2011, pp. 167–222.
* with Stéphane Bijakowski and Benoit Stroh: Classicité des formes modulaires superconvergentes, Annals of Mathematics, Vol. 183, 2016, pp. 975–1014
* with Fabrizio Andreatta and  Adrian Iovita: p-adic families of modular cusp forms, Annals of Mathematics, Vol. 181, 2015, pp. 623–697
* with Andreatta and Iovita: Le Halo Spectral, Ann. Sci. ENS
* with Andreatta and Iovita: [http://users.mat.unimi.it/users/andreat/AIP2.pdf On overconvergent Hilbert modular cusp forms], Astérisque, Vol. 382, 2016, pp. 163–193
* with Benoit Stroh: Surconvergence, ramification et modularité, Astérisque, vol. 382, 2016, pp. 195–266. MR
* Formes modulaires p-adiques de Hilbert de poids 1, Invent. Math., Vol. 208, 2017, pp. 633–676.
* [http://perso.ens-lyon.fr/vincent.pilloni/complexhidatheorygsp4.pdf Higher coherent cohomology and p-adic modular forms of singular weight], 2017
**For preprints, see Pilloni's website.

{{Infobox scientist | name = | image = PixtonAaron MFO17461.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Aaron Pixton at the Workshop ''[[Moduli space|Moduli Spaces]] in Algebraic Geometry'', [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach|Oberwolfach]] 2013 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1986|01|13|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Binghamton, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = [[Harvard University]]
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | alma_mater = [[Princeton University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Rahul Pandharipande]] | doctoral_students = | known_for = | awards = [[Morgan Prize]] (2009) }} '''Aaron C. Pixton''' (born January 13, 1986) is an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. He works in [[enumerative geometry]], and is also known for his [[chess]] playing. ==Early life and education== Pixton was born in [[Binghamton, New York]]; his father, [[Dennis Pixton]], is a retired professor of mathematics at [[Binghamton University]]. He grew up in [[Vestal, New York]]. While a student at [[Vestal Senior High School]], he scored a perfect score on the [[American Mathematics Competition]] three times from 2002–2004.{{cite web | date=May 24, 2002 | url=http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2002-12a/02-1012abperfpaper.html | title=2002 AMC 10A/B & AMC 12A/B Perfect Papers | publisher=University of Nebraska–Lincoln | accessdate=2006-05-24 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823211443/http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2002-12a/02-1012abperfpaper.html | archivedate=August 23, 2006 | df= }}; {{cite web | date=March 30, 2004 | url=http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2003-12a/03perfect1012ab.html | title=2003 - AMC 10 & 12, A&B Perfect Papers | publisher=University of Nebraska–Lincoln | accessdate=2006-05-24 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823184805/http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2003-12a/03perfect1012ab.html | archivedate=August 23, 2006 | df= }}; {{cite web | date=June 17, 2004 | url=http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2004-12a/04perfect1012AB.html#NY-Pixton | title=2004 - AMC 10 & 12, A&B Perfect Papers | publisher=University of Nebraska–Lincoln | accessdate=2006-05-24 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060407234435/http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e6-amc12/e6-1-12archive/2004-12a/04perfect1012AB.html#NY-Pixton | archive-date=2006-04-07 | dead-url=yes | df= }} He went on to the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]] in 2003 and 2004 to win consecutive gold medals.{{cite web |date=September 24, 2003 |url=http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e9-imo/e9-1-imoarchive/2003-ia/03imoteam.html |title=2003 IMO USA Team |publisher=University of Nebraska–Lincoln |accessdate=2006-05-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516105408/http://www.unl.edu/amc/e-exams/e9-imo/e9-1-imoarchive/2003-ia/03imoteam.html |archivedate=2006-05-16 |deadurl=yes |df= }};
