'''Miles Anthony Reid''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 30 January 1948) is a mathematician who works in [[algebraic geometry]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1090/S0894-0347-01-00368-X| year = 2001| last1 = Bridgeland | first1 = T. | authorlink1 = Tom Bridgeland| title = The McKay correspondence as an equivalence of derived categories | journal = Journal of the American Mathematical Society| volume = 14| issue = 3| pages = 535| last2 = King | first2 = A. | last3 = Reid | first3 = M. | authorlink3 = Miles Reid}}</ref>

==Education==
Reid studied the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]] at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and obtained his Ph.D. in 1973 under the supervision of [[Peter Swinnerton-Dyer]] and [[Pierre Deligne]].<ref name=mathgene>{{MathGenealogy|id=70064}}</ref>

==Career==
Reid was a research fellow of [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] from 1973 to 1978.  He became a lecturer at the [[University of Warwick]] in 1978 and was appointed professor there in 1992.  He has written two well known books:  ''Undergraduate Algebraic Geometry'' and ''Undergraduate Commutative Algebra''.

==Awards and honours==
Reid was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 2002. Reid was awarded the [[Berwick Prize|Senior Berwick Prize]] in 2006 for his paper with [[Alessio Corti]] and Aleksandr Pukhlikov, "Fano 3-fold hypersurfaces", which made a big advance in the study of 3-dimensional [[Algebraic variety|algebraic varieties]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Senior Berwick Prize| work = Prize Winners 2006| publisher = LMS| date = 2006-06-19| url = http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/citations06.html| accessdate = 2008-10-15| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090629070434/http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/citations06.html| archivedate = 2009-06-29| df = }}</ref>

==Personal life==
Reid speaks [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and has given lectures in Japanese.

==Bibliography==
His most famous book is

Other books

His most famous translation is the 2-vols book by [[Shafarevich]]

'''Vladimir Abramovich Rokhlin''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Влади́мир Абра́мович Ро́хлин) (23 August 1919 – 3 December 1984) was a [[USSR|Soviet]] [[mathematician]], who made numerous contributions in [[algebraic topology]], [[geometry]], [[measure theory]], [[probability theory]], [[ergodic theory]] and [[entropy|entropy theory]].<ref>see {{harvtxt|Vershik|1989}}, {{harvtxt|Arnol'd|1986}}</ref>

==Life==
Vladimir Abramovich Rokhlin was born in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan Democratic Republic|Azerbaijan]], to a wealthy [[Russian Jewish]] family.<ref>see {{harvtxt|Turaev|Vershik|2001}}, p.8</ref> His mother, Henrietta Emmanuilovna Levenson, had studied medicine in France (she died in Baku in 1923, believed to have been killed during civil unrest provoked by an epidemic). His maternal grandmother, Clara Levenson, had been one of the first female doctors in Russia. His maternal grandfather Emmanuil Levenson was a wealthy businessman (he was also the illegitimate father of [[Korney Chukovsky]], who was thus Henrietta's half-brother).  Vladimir Rokhlin's father Abram Veniaminovich Rokhlin was a well-known social democrat (he was imprisoned  during Stalin's [[Great Purge]], and executed in 1941).<ref>see {{harvtxt|Turaev|Vershik|2001}}, p. 1</ref>

Vladimir Rokhlin entered [[Moscow State University]] in 1935. His advisor was [[Abraham Plessner]]. He volunteered for the army in 1941, leading to four years as a [[Prisoner of war|prisoner]] of a [[List of POW camps in Germany|German war camp]], and then two years in a Soviet checking camp after the end of the war on suspicion of being a German or/and Western spy. Due to intercession by [[Andrey Kolmogorov]] and [[Lev Pontryagin]], he was released and then returned to mathematics.

Since 1959 he was at [[Leningrad State University]], where he was a teacher.

He died in 1984 in [[Leningrad]]. His students include [[Viatcheslav M. Kharlamov|Viatcheslav Kharlamov]], [[Yakov Eliashberg]], [[Mikhail Gromov (mathematician)|Mikhail Gromov]], [[Nikolai V. Ivanov]], [[Anatoly Vershik]] and [[Oleg Viro]].<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=42580|title=Vladimir Abramovich Rokhlin}}</ref>

==Work==
Rokhlin's contributions to topology include [[Rokhlin's theorem]], a result of 1952 on the [[signature (topology)|signature]] of [[4-manifold]]s, which was subsequently generalised by [[Friedrich Hirzebruch]]. He also worked in the theory of [[characteristic class]]es, [[homotopy theory]] and [[cobordism theory]].

In [[measure theory]], Rokhlin introduced what are now called [[Rokhlin partition]]s. He introduced the notion of [[standard probability space]], and characterised such spaces up to [[standard probability space#Isomorphism modulo zero|isomorphism mod 0]]. He also proved the famous [[Rokhlin lemma]].

==Family==
His son [[Vladimir Rokhlin, Jr.]] is a well-known mathematician and computer scientist at [[Yale University]].

Rokhlin's uncle was [[Korney Chukovsky]], a well-known [[Russian language|Russian]] poet, most famous for his popular children's books.

'''Marie-Françoise Roy''' (born 28 April 1950 in [[Paris]]) is a French [[Mathematicians|mathematician]] noted for her work in [[real algebraic geometry]]. She has been Professor of Mathematics at the [[University of Rennes|University of Rennes 1]] since 1985 and in 2009 was made a ''Chevalier'' of the French [[Legion of Honour]].<ref>''[[Journal officiel de la République française]]'' (1 January 2009). [http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?dateTexte=&categorieLien=id&cidTexte=JORFTEXT000020020329&fastPos=3&fastReqId=196080316&oldAction=rechExpTexteJorf "Décret du 31 décembre 2008 portant promotion et nomination"], p. 15.</ref>

==Research==
Roy works in [[real algebraic geometry]] in particular real spectra and, most recently, in complexity of [[algorithms]] in real algebraic geometry and also the applications.<ref>[http://www.espace-sciences.org/archives/science/13583.html Interview in la revue de l'espace de sciences (in French)]</ref>

==Education and career==
Marie-Françoise Roy got her education at [[École Normale Supérieure]][[École normale supérieure de jeunes filles|de jeunes filles]] and was an assistant professor at [[Paris 13 University|Université Paris Nord]] during 1973.<ref>[http://www.ihes.fr/~carbone/papers/women.pdf Women in Mathematics...Why not You? Exhibition in 16 portraits. p.20]</ref> She received her PhD at [[Paris 13 University|Université Paris Nord]] in 1980, supervised by Jean Benabou.<ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=64165}}</ref>

From 1981 she spent two years at [[Abdou Moumouni University]] in [[Niger]]. In 1985 she became a professor at [[University of Rennes|University of Rennes 1]] in [[Rennes]], [[France]].

==Service==
Roy was president of [[Société Mathématique de France]] from 2004 to 2007.<ref>[http://smf.emath.fr/content/anciens-presidents Past presidents of Société Mathématique de France (in French)]</ref>

In 1986, Roy was one of the founders<ref>[http://www.drivehq.com/file/df.aspx?isGallary=true&shareID=8755087&fileID=748744287 Newsletter of the AWM, October 1986] p.1</ref> of [http://www.europeanwomeninmaths.org/ European Women in Mathematics], EWM, and is the convenor (president) of EWM 2009-2013.<ref>[http://www.europeanwomeninmaths.org/women-in-math/portrait/marie-francoise-roy EWM, Portrait of Marie-Francoise Roy]</ref> In 1987 she co-founded the French organization for women in mathematics, [[L'association femmes et mathématiques|Femmes et Mathématiques]], and became the organization's first president.

Roy is scientific officer for Sub-Saharan Africa in [http://www.cimpa-icpam.org/  Centre International de Mathématiques Pures et Appliquées,CIMPA].<ref>[http://www.cimpa-icpam.org/spip.php?rubrique45&lang=en CIMPA website]</ref> Roy is president of [http://www.tarbiyya-tatali.org/?-English-  Association d'Echanges Culturels Cesson Dankassari (Tarbiyya-Tatali)] an organization working for joint activities in a commune [[Dan-Kassari|Dan-Cassari]] in [[Niger]] and the French commune [[Cesson-Sévigné]].

pages.title: Kyoji Saito
pages.text:
[[File:Saito pham trung greuel.jpg|thumb|from left: Ngo Viet Trung, Kyoji Saito, [[Frédéric Pham]], Gert-Martin Greuel at [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach|Oberwolfach]] in 2009]]
'''Kyōji Saitō''' (齋藤 恭司, Saitō Kyōji; born 25 December 1944)<ref>information from [http://errol.oclc.org/laf/n95086251.html LCCN]</ref> is a [[Japan]]ese [[mathematician]], specializing in [[algebraic geometry]] and [[complex geometry|complex analytic geometry]].

==Educationa and career==
Saito received in 1971 his [[Promotion (Germany)|promotion]] [[Ph.D.]] from the [[University of Göttingen]] under [[Egbert Brieskorn]], with thesis ''Quasihomogene isolierte Singularitäten von Hyperflächen'' (Quasihomogeneous isolated singularities of hypersurfaces.<ref name="gen">{{MathGenealogy|id=76983}}</ref> Saito is a professor at the [[Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences]] (RIMS) of [[Kyoto University]].

Saito's research deals with the interplay among  [[Lie algebra]]s, [[reflection group]]s ([[Coxeter group]]s),<ref>{{cite journal|author=Saito, Kyoji|title=A new relation among Cartan matrix and Coveter matrix|journal=Journal of Algebra|volume=105|issue=1|year=1987|pages=149–158|doi=10.1016/0021-8693(87)90183-9}}</ref> [[braid group]]s, and [[Singular point of an algebraic variety|singularities]] of [[hypersurface]]s.

From the 1980s, he did research on underlying symmetries of period integrals in complex hypersurfaces. Saito introduced higher-dimensional generalizations of [[elliptic integral]]s. These generalizations are integrals of "primitive forms",<ref>{{cite arxiv|author=Saito, Kyoji|title=From primitive form to mirror symmetry|eprint=1408.4208|year=2014|class=math.AG}}</ref> first considered in the study of the unfolding of isolated singularities of complex hypersurfaces, associated with infinite-dimensional Lie algebras. He also studied the corresponding new automorphic forms.<ref>[http://www.ipmu.jp/kyoji-saito Kyoji Saito] at the [[Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe]]</ref> The theory has a geometric connection to "flat structures" (now called "Saito Frobenius manifolds"),<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Belavin, Alexander|authorlink=Alexander Belavin|author2=Gepner, Doron|authorlink2=Doron Gepner|author3=Kononov, Yakov|title=Flat coordinates for Saito Frobenius manifolds and string theory|journal=Theoretical and Mathematical Physics|volume=189|issue=3|pages=1775|year=2016|arxiv=1510.06970|doi=10.1134/S0040577916120096|bibcode=2016TMP...189.1775B}}</ref> [[Mirror symmetry (string theory)|mirror symmetry]], [[Frobenius manifold]]s, and [[Gromov–Witten invariant|Gromov–Witten theory]] in algebraic geometry and various topics in mathematical physics related to [[string theory]].

Saito supervised the thesis of 7 Ph.D. students at Kyoto University, including [[Hiroaki Terao]] and Masahiko Yoshinaga.<ref name="gen"/>

He was an Invited Speaker with talk ''The limit element in the configuration algebra for a discrete group: a prècis'' at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] 1990 in Kyoto. In 2011 he was awarded the Geometry Prize of the [[Mathematical Society of Japan]].

pages.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=April 2009}} {{COI|date=April 2009}} }} {{Infobox scientist | name = Wilfried Schmid | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|05|28|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Hamburg]], [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[German American]] | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = [[Harvard University]]
[[Columbia University]] | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = [[Phillip Griffiths]] | doctoral_students = [[Carlos Simpson]] | known_for = | awards = }} '''Wilfried Schmid''' (born May 28, 1943) is a [[Germans|German]]-[[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] who works in [[Hodge theory]], [[representation theory]], and [[automorphic form]]s. He earned his [[Ph.D.]] at [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1967 under the direction of [[Phillip Griffiths]], and then taught at Berkeley and [[Columbia University]], becoming a Full Professor at Columbia at age 27. In 1978 he moved to [[Harvard University]], where he is currently the Dwight Parker Robinson Professor of Mathematics. Schmid's early work concerns the construction of [[discrete series representation]]s of semi-simple [[Lie group]]s. Notable accomplishments here include a proof of Langlands' conjecture on the [[discrete series]], along with a later proof (joint with [[Michael Atiyah]]) constructing all such discrete series representations on spaces of harmonic spinors. Schmid along with his student Henryk Hecht proved [[Blattner's conjecture]] in 1975. In the 1970s he described the singularities of the Griffith's period map by applying [[Lie theory|Lie-theoretic method]]s to problems in [[algebraic geometry]]. Schmid has been very involved in K–12 mathematics education both nationally and internationally. His interest arose in 1999 after being disturbed by the experiences of his 2nd-grade daughter in her mathematics class. He was heavily involved in the drafting of the Massachusetts Mathematics Curriculum Framework in 2000. Later, he served on the National Mathematics Advisory Panel of the U.S. Department of Education.[http://www2.ed.gov/about/bdscomm/list/mathpanel/bios/schmid.html Biography of Dr. Wilfried Schmid] In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-07-14. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{MathGenealogy |id=31755 |name=Wilfried Schmid}} *[http://www.math.harvard.edu/~schmid/ Schmid's Harvard website] *[http://www.ed.gov/about/bdscomm/list/mathpanel/bios/schmid.html National Mathematics Panel Biography] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schmid, Wilfried}} [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:German mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Differential geometers]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:People from Hamburg]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]]

[[Fields Medal]] (2018) | children = 1 }} '''Peter Scholze''' (born 11 December 1987){{cite web |title=Prof. Dr. Peter Scholze |url=http://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de:80/people/faculty/hausdorff-chairs/profile/peter-scholze/ |publisher=[[Hausdorff Center for Mathematics]] |accessdate=1 August 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426161858/http://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de:80/people/faculty/hausdorff-chairs/profile/peter-scholze/ |archivedate=26 April 2017}} is a German [[mathematician]] known for his work in [[algebraic geometry]]. He has been a professor at the [[University of Bonn]] since 2012, and director at the [[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]] since 2018. He has been called one of the leading mathematicians in the world.{{cite web |title=Mathematiker Peter Scholze (24) nimmt Ruf nach Bonn an – als jüngster deutscher W3-Professor |url=https://idw-online.de/de/news501513 |website=[[Informationsdienst Wissenschaft]] |accessdate=1 August 2018 |language=German |date=15 October 2012}}{{cite web |title=Leibniz Prize 2016: Professor Dr. Peter Scholze |url=http://www.dfg.de/en/funded_projects/prizewinners/leibniz_prize/2016/scholze/index.html |publisher=[[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] |accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/peter-scholze-becomes-one-of-the-youngest-fields-medalists-ever-20180801/|last=Klarreich|first=Erica|title=A Master of Numbers and Shapes Who Is Rewriting Arithmetic|work=Quanta Magazine|date=1 August 2018|access-date=2 August 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Kaschel |first1=Helena |title=Don't call me a prodigy: the rising stars of European mathematics |url=https://www.dw.com/en/dont-call-me-a-prodigy-the-rising-stars-of-european-mathematics/a-19421389 |accessdate=2 August 2018 |work=Deutsche Welle |date=23 July 2016 |language=English}} He won the [[Fields Medal]] in 2018, which is regarded as the highest professional honor in mathematics.{{Cite journal|last=Ball|first=Philip|title=Iranian is first woman to nab highest prize in maths|url=https://www.nature.com/news/iranian-is-first-woman-to-nab-highest-prize-in-maths-1.15686|journal=Nature|language=en|date=12 August 2014|accessdate=4 November 2018|doi=10.1038/nature.2014.15686}}{{Cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Honours/FieldsMedal.html|title=Fields Medal|publisher=School of Mathematics and Statistics – University of St Andrews, Scotland|access-date=29 March 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.uchicago.edu/about/accolades/14/|title=Fields Medal|publisher=The University of Chicago|language=en|access-date=29 March 2018}} == Early life and education == Scholze was born in [[Dresden]] and grew up in [[Berlin]].{{cite web |title=Zwei Forscher der Uni Bonn erhalten den Leibniz-Preis |url=https://www.uni-bonn.de/neues/279-2015 |publisher=Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität Bonn |accessdate=1 August 2018 |language=German |date=10 December 2015 |quote=Peter Scholze wurde 1987 in Dresden geboren und wuchs auf in Berlin.}} His father is a [[physicist]], his mother a [[computer scientist]], and his sister studied [[chemistry]].{{cite web |author=[[Centre International de Rencontres Mathématiques]] |title=Interview at CIRM: Peter Scholze |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J0QdTYZIfIM |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=23 December 2018 |date=29 June 2015}} He attended the {{Interlanguage link multi|Heinrich-Hertz-Gymnasium|de|3=Heinrich-Hertz-Gymnasium (Berlin)}} in [[Friedrichshain|Berlin-Friedrichshain]], a [[Gymnasium (Germany)|gymnasium]] devoted to mathematics and science.{{cite news |title=Mit ihm kann man rechnen |url=https://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/mit-ihm-kann-man-rechnen/629972.html |accessdate=1 August 2018 |work=[[Der Tagesspiegel]] |date=3 August 2005 |language=German}} As a student, Scholze participated in the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]], winning three gold medals and one silver medal.{{Cite web|url=http://imo-official.org/participant_r.aspx?id=7867|title=International Mathematical Olympiad|last=Dolinar|first=Gregor|website=International Mathematical Olympiad|access-date=1 August 2018}} He studied at the [[University of Bonn]] and completed his [[Bachelor's degree]] in three semesters and his [[Master's degree]] in two further semesters.{{Cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/studium/24-jaehriges-mathe-genie-wird-deutschlands-juengster-professor-a-861373.html|title=Mathe-Genie: 24-Jähriger wird Deutschlands jüngster Professor|date=16 October 2012|work=Spiegel Online|access-date=1 August 2018|language=German}} He obtained his Ph.D. in 2012 under the supervision of [[Michael Rapoport]]. ==Career== From July 2011 until 2016, Scholze was a Research Fellow of the [[Clay Mathematics Institute]] in New Hampshire.{{cite web |title=Peter Scholze |url=http://www.claymath.org/people/peter-scholze-1 |publisher=[[Clay Mathematics Institute]] |accessdate=1 August 2018}} In 2012 shortly after completing his PhD, he was made full professor at the University of Bonn, becoming the youngest full professor in Germany at the age of 24.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bild.de/news/inland/mathematiker/mathe-genie-peter-scholze-juengster-professor-bonn-26715142.bild.html|title=Peter Scholze ist erst 24 Jahre alt: Mathe-Genie wird Deutschlands jüngster Professor|date=15 October 2012|work=Bild|access-date=1 August 2018|language=de}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/berlin/hochschule-mathematikgenie-aus-berlin,10809148,20602974.html|title=Hochschule: Mathematikgenie aus Berlin|last=Harmsen|first=Torsten|date=15 October 2012|work=Berliner Zeitung|access-date=1 August 2018|language=de-DE}} In Fall 2014, Scholze was appointed the Chancellor's Professor at [[University of California, Berkeley]], where he taught a course on [[P-adic analysis|p-adic geometry]].{{Cite web|url=https://math.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/peter-scholze|title=Peter Scholze|publisher=Department of Mathematics at University of California Berkeley|language=en|access-date=1 August 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.math.uni-bonn.de/people/scholze/Berkeley.pdf|title=Berkeley lectures on p-adic geometry|last1=Scholze|first1=Peter|last2=Weinstein|first2=Jared|date=October 2018|website=University of Bonn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 November 2018}} In 2018, Scholze was appointed as a director of the [[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]] in Bonn.{{cite web |title=Peter Scholze new director at the Max Planck Institute for Mathematics |url=https://www.mpim-bonn.mpg.de/node/8461 |publisher=[[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]] |accessdate=11 July 2018 |language=en |date=2 July 2018}} == Work == Scholze's work has concentrated on purely local aspects of [[arithmetic geometry]] such as [[p-adic number|''p''-adic]] geometry and its applications. He presented in a more compact form some of the previous fundamental theories pioneered by [[Gerd Faltings]], [[Jean-Marc Fontaine]] and later by [[Kiran Kedlaya]]. His PhD thesis on [[perfectoid space]]s{{cite journal |last1=Scholze |first1=Peter |title=Perfectoid Spaces |journal=[[Publications Mathématiques de l'IHÉS]] |date=November 2012 |volume=116 |issue=1 |pages=245–313 |doi=10.1007/s10240-012-0042-x}} yields the solution to a special case of the [[weight-monodromy conjecture]].{{cite web|last=Scholze|first=Peter|url=http://www.math.uni-bonn.de/people/scholze/CDM.pdf|title=Perfectoid spaces: A survey|website=University of Bonn|accessdate=4 November 2018}} == Awards == In 2012, he was awarded the Prix and Cours Peccot.{{cite web|url=http://www.college-de-france.fr/media/cours-peccot/UPL1466994975427365342_LISTE_CHRONOLOGIQUE_DES_INTITULES_DES_COURS_PECCOT_DEPUIS_1899_.pdf|title=College de France|publisher=}} He was awarded the 2013 [[SASTRA Ramanujan Prize]].{{cite web |title=Peter Scholze to receive 2013 Sastra Ramanujan Prize |url=http://www.sastra.edu/index.php/headlines-archives/990-peter-scholze-to-receive-2013-sastra-ramanujan-prize |publisher=[[Shanmugha Arts, Science, Technology & Research Academy]] |accessdate=1 August 2018}} In 2014, he received the [[Clay Research Award]].{{cite web |title=2014 Clay Research Awards |url=http://www.claymath.org/events/news/2014-clay-research-awards |publisher=Clay Mathematics Institute |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=14 July 2014}} In 2015, he was awarded the [[Frank Nelson Cole Prize]] in Algebra,{{cite web |title=Peter Scholze to Receive 2015 AMS Cole Prize in Algebra |url=http://www.ams.org/news?news_id=2500 |publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]] |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=4 December 2014}} and the [[Ostrowski Prize]].{{cite web |title=The prize and the prize winners |url=https://ostrowski.ch/index_e.php?ifile=preis |publisher=Ostrowski Foundation |accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{cite web |title=Ostrowski Prize 2015: Peter Scholze |url=https://ostrowski.ch/pdf/preis2015.pdf |publisher=Ostrowski Foundation |accessdate=1 August 2018}} He received the [[Fermat Prize]] 2015 from the Institut de Mathématiques de Toulouse.{{cite web |title=Lauréats du Prix Fermat |url=https://www.math.univ-toulouse.fr/spip.php?article737&lang=fr |publisher=[[Institut de Mathématiques de Toulouse]] |accessdate=1 August 2018}} In 2016, he was awarded the [[Leibniz Prize]] 2016 by the [[German Research Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dfg.de/en/service/press/press_releases/2015/press_release_no_58/index.html|title=Leibniz Prizes 2016: DFG Honours Ten Researchers|date=10 December 2015|publisher=[[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]]|accessdate=3 January 2016}} He declined the $100,000 "New Horizons in Mathematics Prize" of the 2016 [[Breakthrough Prize in Mathematics|Breakthrough Prize]]s.{{Cite web |title= 2016 Breakthrough Prizes |url= https://breakthroughprize.org/News/29 |website= breakthroughprize.org |accessdate= 15 November 2015 }} His turning down of the prize received little media attention.{{cite web |last1=Woit |first1=Peter |title=2016 Breakthrough Prizes |url=http://www.math.columbia.edu/~woit/wordpress/?p=8088 |website=Not Even Wrong |publisher=Department of Mathematics at Columbia University |accessdate=3 August 2018 |date=9 November 2015}} He was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 2018,{{cite news |last1=Chang |first1=Kenneth |title=Fields Medals Awarded to 4 Mathematicians |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/01/science/fields-medals-mathematics.html |accessdate=1 August 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=1 August 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/mensch/peter-scholze-deutscher-mathematiker-bekommt-fields-medaille-a-1215660.html|title=Fields-Medaille: Peter Scholze bekommt weltweit höchste Auszeichnung für Mathematiker|last=Dambeck|first=Holger|date=1 August 2018|work=Spiegel Online|access-date=1 August 2018|language=German}} for "transforming arithmetic [[algebraic geometry]] over [[p-adic]] fields through his introduction of [[perfectoid space]]s, with application to [[Galois representations]], and for the development of new [[cohomology]] theories."{{cite web |title=Fields Medals 2018 |url=https://www.mathunion.org/imu-awards/fields-medal/fields-medals-2018 |publisher=[[International Mathematical Union]] |accessdate=2 August 2018}} == Personal life == Scholze is married to a fellow mathematician{{cite news |last1=Schmundt |first1=Hilmar |title=Bildung: Lieber Mathe als Rockband |url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-144430358.html |accessdate=15 August 2018 |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=23 April 2016 |language=German}} and has a daughter.{{cite news |last1=Klarreich |first1=Erica |authorlink=Erica Klarreich |title=The Oracle of Arithmetic |url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/peter-scholze-and-the-future-of-arithmetic-geometry-20160628/ |accessdate=15 August 2018 |work=[[Quanta Magazine]]|date=28 June 2016}} == References == [[Schubert calculus]] | prizes = | footnotes = }} '''Hermann Cäsar Hannibal Schubert''' (22 May 1848 – 20 July 1911){{MacTutor Biography|id=Schubert}} was a [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]]. Schubert was one of the leading developers of [[enumerative geometry]], which considers those parts of [[algebraic geometry]] that involve a finite number of solutions. In 1874, Schubert won a prize for solving a question posed by [[Hieronymus Georg Zeuthen|Zeuthen]]. [[Schubert calculus]] was named after him. Schubert tutored [[Adolf Hurwitz]] at the Realgymnasium Andreanum in [[Hildesheim]], [[Hanover]], and arranged for Hurwitz to study under [[Felix Klein]] at University. ==See also== * Schubert cycle or [[Schubert variety]] * [[Schubert polynomial]] ==Publications== *{{citation|mr=0555576 |last=Schubert|first= Hermann |title=Kalkül der abzählenden Geometrie|language=German |series=Reprint of the 1879 original|editor-first=Steven L. |editor-last=Kleiman|publisher= Springer-Verlag|place= Berlin-New York|year= 1979|isbn= 3-540-09233-1 |origyear=1879|url=https://archive.org/details/kalklderabzh00schuuoft}} ==References== {{Reflist}} *Werner Burau and Bodo Renschuch, "Ergänzungen zur Biographie von Hermann Schubert," (Complements to the biography of Hermann Schubert,) ''Mitt. Math. Ges. Hamb.'' pages.title: Richard Schwartz (mathematician)
pages.text:
'''Richard Evan Schwartz''' (born August 11, 1966) is an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] notable for his contributions<ref name=twsZA32/> to [[geometric group theory]] and to an area of [[mathematics]] known as [[Outer billiard|billiards]].<ref name=twsZA32>{{cite journal
 |title= Journal articles by Richard Evan Schwartz
 |publisher= ''SpringerLink''
 |quote= Elementary Surprises in Projective Geometry – Discrete monodromy, pentagrams, and the method of condensation – The quasi-isometry classification of rank one lattices – Degenerating the complex hyperbolic ideal triangle groups – Quasi-isometric rigidity and diophantine approximation – A Conformal Averaging Process on the Circle – Desargues Theorem, Dynamics, and Hyperplane Arrangements – The Density of Shapes in Three-Dimensional Barycentric Subdivision – Real hyperbolic on the outside, complex hyperbolic on the inside – Symmetric patterns of geodesics and automorphisms of surface groups
 |date= 1996–2010
 |url= http://www.springerlink.com/content/c5563w587u548418/
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
 |doi=10.1007/BF02392599
}}</ref> Geometric group theory is a relatively new area of mathematics beginning around the late 1980s<ref name="M. Gromov, 1987, pp. 75–263">M. Gromov, ''Hyperbolic Groups'', in "Essays in Group Theory" (G. M. Gersten, ed.), MSRI Publ. 8, 1987, pp. 75–263.</ref> which explores finitely generated groups, and seeks connections between their algebraic properties and the geometric spaces on which these groups act. He has worked on what mathematicians refer to as ''[[Outer billiard|billiards]]'', which are [[dynamical system]]s based on a [[convex set|convex]] shape in a plane. He has explored geometric iterations involving [[polygons]],<ref name=twsZA28/> and he has been credited for developing the mathematical concept known as the [[pentagram map]]. In addition, he is a bestselling author of a mathematics picture book for young children.<ref name=twsZA17>{{cite news
 |title= Top 10/Top5/Editor’s Picks/Editor’s Note
 |newspaper= Brown Daily Herald
 |quote= BOOKS is braving the number jungle with the help of You Can Count on Monsters, a picture book by Brown prof Richard Schwartz that may just cure our childhood fear of factoring.
 |date= 3 Feb 2011
 |url= http://post.browndailyherald.com/2011/02/03/top-10top5editors-pickseditors-note/
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> His published work usually appears under the name ''Richard Evan Schwartz''. In 2018 he is a professor of mathematics at [[Brown University]].<ref name=twsZA18>{{cite news
 |author= Valentin Ovsienko, Richard Schwartz, and [[Sergei Tabachnikov]]
 |title= Quasiperiodic Motion for the Pentagram Map
 |publisher= ''Google User Content''
 |quote= Richard Evan Schwartz: Department of Mathematics, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, USA, 
 |date= 2011-06-27
 |url= http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:n7nhhKrt6TcJ:hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/35/18/32/PS/era.ps+%22richard+evan+schwartz%22+Sergei+Tabachnikov+Valentin+Ovsienko&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us&client=ubuntu&source=www.google.com
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref>

==Career==
Schwartz was born in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] on August 11, 1966. In his youth he played [[tennis]] and enjoyed [[video games]]. He attended [[John F. Kennedy High School (Los Angeles)|John F. Kennedy High School]] in Los Angeles from 1981 to 1984, then earned a [[Bachelor's degree|B. S.]] in [[mathematics]] from [[University of California, Los Angeles|U.C.L.A.]] in 1987, and then a [[Doctorate|Ph. D.]] in [[mathematics]] from [[Princeton University]] in 1991 under the supervision of [[William Thurston]].<ref>http://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=18909</ref> He taught at the [[University of Maryland]]. He is currently the Chancellor's Professor of Mathematics at [[Brown University]]. He lives with his wife and two daughters in [[Barrington, Rhode Island]].

Schwartz is credited by other mathematicians for introducing the concept of the [[pentagram map]].<ref name=twsZA28>{{cite arXiv
 |author= Fedor Soloviev
 |title= Integrability of the Pentagram Map
 |quote= The pentagram map was introduced by R. Schwartz in 1992 for convex planar polygons. ... arXiv:1106.3950v2 – math.AG –
 |date= 27 Jun 2011
 |eprint= 1106.3950
 }}</ref>
According to Schwartz's conception, a convex polygon would be inscribed with diagonal lines inside it, by drawing a line from one point to the next point—that is, by skipping over the immediate point on the polygon. The intersection points of the diagonals would form an inner polygon, and the process could be repeated.<ref name=twsZA24>{{cite arXiv
 |author= Max Glick
 |title= The pentagram map and Y-patterns
 |quote= The pentagram map, introduced by R. Schwartz, is defined by the following construction: given a polygon as input, draw all of its "shortest" diagonals, and output the smaller polygon which they cut out. We employ the machinery of cluster algebras to obtain explicit formulas for the iterates of the pentagram map. 
 |date= 15 Apr 2011
 |eprint= 1005.0598
 }}</ref> Schwartz observed these geometric patterns, partly by experimenting with computers.<ref name=twsZA23>{{cite news
 |author1=Richard Evan Schwartz |author2=Serge Tabachnikov |title= The Pentagram Integrals on Inscribed Polygons
 |publisher= ''Mendeley''
 |quote= The pentagram map is a natural iteration on projective equivalence classes of (twisted) n-gons in the projective plane. It was recently proved (OST) that the pentagram map is completely integrable, with the complete set of Poisson commuting integrals given by the polynomials O1,...,On/2,On and E1,...,En/2,En, previously constructed in S3. These polynomials are somewhat reminiscent of the symmetric polynomials. It was observed in computer experiments that if a polygon is inscribed into a conic then Oi=Ei for all i. The goal of the paper is to prove this theorem. The proof is combinatorial, and it was also suggested by computer experimentation.
 |year= 2010
 |url= http://www.mendeley.com/research/pentagram-integrals-inscribed-polygons-7/
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> 
He has collaborated with mathematicians Valentin Ovsienko<ref name=twsZA26>{{cite news
 |author= V Ovsienko
 |title= The Pentagram map: a discrete integrable system
 |publisher= ''University of Cambridge''
 |quote= (academic lecture by mathematician V Ovsienko on the pentagram map subject)
 |date= 2011-06-27
 |url= http://www.sms.cam.ac.uk/media/536614
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> 
and [[Sergei Tabachnikov]]<ref name=twsZA21>{{cite journal
 |author1=Valentin Ovsienko |author2=Richard Schwartz |author3=Serge Tabachnikov |title= The Pentagram Map: A Discrete Integrable System
 |publisher= ''Microsoft Academic Search''
 |quote= The pentagram map is a projectively natural iteration defined on polygons, and also on objects we call twisted polygons (a twisted polygon is a map from Z into the projective plane that is periodic modulo a projective transformation). We find a Poisson structure on the space of twisted polygons and show that the pentagram map relative to this Poisson structure is completely integrable in the sense of Arnold–Liouville. For certain families of twisted polygons, such as those we call universally convex, we translate the integrability into a statement about the quasi-periodic motion for the dynamics of the pentagram map. We also explain how the pentagram map, in the continuous limit, corresponds to the classical Boussinesq equation. The Poisson structure we attach to the pentagram map is a discrete version of the first Poisson structure associated with the Boussinesq equation. Journal: Communications in Mathematical Physics – COMMUN MATH PHYS , vol. 299, no. 2, pp. 409–446, 2010 {{doi|10.1007/s00220-010-1075-y}} 
 |doi= 10.1007/s00220-010-1075-y 
 |pages= 409–446
 |year= 2010
 |url= http://academic.research.microsoft.com/Publication/5128335/the-pentagram-map-a-discrete-integrable-system
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
 |volume=299
 |journal=Communications in Mathematical Physics
|arxiv=0810.5605|bibcode=2010CMaPh.299..409O}}</ref> 
to show that the pentagram map is  "completely integrable."<ref name=twsZA22>{{cite journal
 |author1=Valentin Ovsienko |author2=Richard Schwartz |author3=Serge Tabachnikov |title= Journal of Fixed Point Theory and Applications
 |publisher= ''Springerlink''
 |quote= This paper studies the pentagram map, a projectively natural iteration on the space of polygons. Inspired by a method from the theory of ordinary differential equations, the paper constructs roughly n algebraically independent invariants for the map, when it is defined on the space of ''n''-gons. These invariants strongly suggest that the pentagram map is a discrete completely integrable system. The paper also relates the pentagram map to Dodgson’s method of condensation for computing determinants, also known as the octahedral recurrence. Journal of Fixed Point Theory and Applications, Volume 3, Number 2, 379–409, {{doi|10.1007/s11784-008-0079-0}}
 |date= 2011-06-27
 |url= http://www.springerlink.com/content/627311749037p274/
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
 |doi=10.1007/s11784-008-0079-0
 |volume=3
 |journal=Journal of Fixed Point Theory and Applications
 |pages=379–409
|arxiv=0709.1264}}</ref>

In his spare time he draws [[comic book]]s,<ref name=twsZA15/> writes computer programs, listens to [[music]] and exercises. He admired the late [[Russia]]n mathematician [[Vladimir Arnold]] and dedicated a paper to him.<ref name=twsZA22/> He played an [[April Fool's joke]] on fellow mathematics professors at Brown University by sending an email suggesting that students could be admitted randomly, along with references to bogus studies which purportedly suggested that there were benefits to having a certain population of the student body selected at random; the story was reported in the ''[[Brown Daily Herald]]''.<ref name=twsZA16>{{cite news
 |title= Merit blind admissions fool math profs on April 1st.
 |newspaper= Brown Daily Herald
 |date= April 17, 2008
 |url= http://www.browndailyherald.com/features/merit-blind-admissions-fool-math-profs-on-april-1-1.1670332
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> Colleagues such as mathematician Jeffrey Brock describe Schwartz as having a "very wry sense of humor."<ref name=twsZA16/>

In 2003, Schwartz was teaching one of his young daughters about number basics and developed a poster of the first 100 numbers using colorful monsters. This project gelled into a mathematics book published in 2010, entitled ''You Can Count on Monsters'' for young children which became a bestseller.<ref name=twsZA15/> Each monster has a graphic which gives a mini-lesson about its properties, such as being a [[prime number]] or a lesson about [[factorization|factoring]]; for example, the graphic monster for the number five was a five-sided star or [[pentagram]].<ref name=twsZA15/> He estimated that he wrote the book during 1000 hours.<ref name=twsZA15/> A year after publication, it was featured prominently on ''[[National Public Radio]]'' in January 2011 and became a bestseller for a few days on the online bookstore [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]<ref name=twsZA15/> as well as earning international acclaim.<ref name=twsZA13>{{cite news
 |author= PRNewsWire News Releases
 |title= You Can Count on Monsters Proclaimed a Self-Learning Tool That Makes Math Fun
 |newspaper= Boston Globe
 |quote= You Can Count on Monsters, a creatively educational children's book that illustrates prime and composite numbers through colorful monsters-themed geometrical designs, has earned international acclaim and stellar sales since its January debut on NPR's Weekend Edition. 
 |date= March 21, 2011
 |url= http://finance.boston.com/boston/news/read?GUID=17856440
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' suggested that the book helped to "take the scariness out of arithmetic."<ref name=twsZA12>{{cite news
 |title= Summer reading: Children's books
 |newspaper= Los Angeles Times
 |quote= Richard Evan Schwartz – CRC Press: $24.95, ages 4-8 – Math is more fun when monsters are along! This colorful illustrated journey through the factor trees of 1–100 features a different creature for each prime number to help take the scariness out of arithmetic.
 |date= May 22, 2011
 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/22/entertainment/la-ca-summer-childrens-20110522
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> Mathematician Keith Devlin, on ''NPR'', agreed, saying that Schwartz "very skillfully and subtly embeds mathematical ideas into the drawings."<ref name=twsZA11>{{cite news
 |author= NPR Staff
 |title= Math Isn't So Scary With Help From These Monsters
 |publisher= ''NPR''
 |quote= Richard Evan Schwartz, a math professor at Brown University, has written and illustrated a children's book called You Can Count On Monsters. Mathematician Keith Devlin talks with NPR's Scott Simon about how the book makes finding prime numbers fun. "This is one of the most amazing math books for kids I have ever seen…," Devlin says. "Great colors, it's wonderful, and yet because [Schwartz] knows the mathematics, he very skillfully and subtly embeds mathematical ideas into the drawings." What Schwartz does is draw monsters to represent different prime and composite numbers.
 |date= January 22, 2011
 |url= https://www.npr.org/2011/01/22/133118069/math-isnt-so-scary-with-help-from-these-monsters
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref> 
He's been compared to a mathematical version of [[Dr. Seuss]].
<ref name=twsZA15>{{cite news
 |author= Ben Kutner
 |title= Math and monsters add up in children’s book
 |newspaper= Brown Daily Herald
 |date= February 2, 2011
 |url= http://www.browndailyherald.com/math-and-monsters-add-up-in-children-s-book-1.2455113
 |accessdate= 2011-06-27
}}</ref>

==Publications==

===Selected contributions===
*The [[quasi-isometry]] classification of rank one lattices:  Any quasi-isometry of a [[hyperbolic space|hyperbolic]] lattice is equivalent to a [[commensurator]].
*A proof  of the 1989  [[William Goldman (mathematician)|Goldman]]–Parker conjecture:  This is a complete description of the [[moduli space]] of the complex hyperbolic ideal triangle groups.
*A proof that a [[triangle]] has a periodic [[Dynamical billiards|billiard]] path provided all its angles are less than 100 degrees
*A solution of the 1960 [[Jürgen Moser|Moser]]–[[Bernard Neumann|Neumann]] problem:  There exists an [[outer billiard]]s system with an unbounded orbit.
*A solution of the 5-[[electron]] case of  [[J. J. Thomson]]'s 1904 [[Thomson problem|problem]]:  The [[triangular bipyramid]] is the configuration of 5 electrons on the [[sphere]] that minimizes the [[Coulomb potential]].
*The introduction of the [[pentagram map]] and a later proof (with Sergei Tabachnikov and Valentin Ovsienko) of its complete [[Integrable system|integrability]].

===Corresponding articles===

 |quote= Meet children’s book authors: Mary Jane Begin, author of "Willow Buds" and Liz Goulet Dubois, author of "What Kind of Rabbit Are You?" (10 a.m.–noon); Karen Dugan, author of "Ms. April & Ms. Mae" and Richard Evan Schwartz, author of "You Can Count on Monsters" (noon–2 p.m.);
 |date= May 11, 2010
 |url= http://www.projo.com/books/content/bkweek11_05-11-10_BKIAAAR_v11.2372bfd.html

}}</ref>

pages.title: Corrado Segre
pages.text:
{{distinguish|Beniamino Segre}} {{short description|Italian mathematician (1863–1924)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Corrado Segre | box_width = | image = Corrado Segre.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1863|8|20}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1924|5|18|1863|8|20}} | birth_place = [[Saluzzo]], Italy | death_place = [[Turin]], Italy | nationality = Italian | field = Mathematics | alma_mater = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = [[Gino Fano]]
[[Beniamino Segre]]
[[Francesco Severi]] | known_for = [[Segre classification]]
[[Segre cubic]]
[[Segre embedding]]
[[Segre surface]]
[[Zeuthen–Segre invariant]] | notable_students = | awards = }} '''Corrado Segre''' (20 August 1863 – 18 May 1924) was an [[Italians|Italian]] [[mathematician]] who is remembered today as a major contributor to the early development of [[algebraic geometry]].{{cite book | author = American Mathematical Society | title = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society | publisher = Society | year = 1924 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=h4XxAAAAMAAJ | access-date = 7 October 2018 | page = 571 | quote = Professor Corrado Segre, of the University of Turin, distinguished for his work in geometry, died May 18, 1924, at the ... }} == Early life == Corrado's parents were Abramo Segre and Estella De Benedetti. == Career == Segre developed his entire career at the [[University of Turin]], first as a student of [[Enrico D'Ovidio]]. In 1883 he published a dissertation on [[quadric]]s in [[projective space]] and was named as assistant to professors in algebra and [[analytic geometry]]. In 1885 he also assisted in [[descriptive geometry]]. He began to instruct in projective geometry, as stand-in for [[Giuseppe Bruno (mathematician)|Giuseppe Bruno]], from 1885 to 1888. Then for 36 years he had the chair in higher geometry following D'Ovidio. Segre and [[Giuseppe Peano]] made Turin known in geometry, and their complementary instruction has been noted as follows:Maurizio Avellone, Aldo Brigaglia & Carmela Zappulla (2002) "The Foundations of Projective Geometry in Italy from De Paolis to Pieri", ''Archive for History of Exact Sciences'' 56:363–425, esp 378 {{quote|"in the mid 1880's, these two very young researchers, Segre and Peano, both of them only just past twenty and both working at the University of Turin, were developing very advanced points of view on fundamental geometrical issues. Although their positions were quite different from one another, they were in some way more complementary than opposed. So it must come as no surprise that Turin was the cradle of some of the most interesting studies on such issues."}} The [[Erlangen program]] of [[Felix Klein]] appealed early on to Segre, and he became a promulgator. First, in 1885 he published an article on conics in the plane where he demonstrated how group theory facilitated the study. As Hawkins says (page 252) "the totality of all conics in the plane is identified with P5(C)". The group of its projectivities is then the group that permutes conics. About Segre, Hawkins writesThomas Hawkins (2000) ''Emergence of the Theory of Lie Groups: an essay in the history of mathematics, 1869 – 1926'', Springer {{ISBN|0-387-98963-3}} {{quote|"shortly after he assumed the chair of projective geometry in Turin in 1888, he decided it would be worthwhile to have an Italian translation of the ''Erlangen Program'' because he felt its contents were not well enough known among young Italian geometers. ... Segre convinced one of the students at Turin, [[Gino Fano]], to make a translation which was published in ''Annali di Matematica Pura ed Applicata'' in 1889. Fano's translation thus became the first of many translations of the ''Erlangen Program''."}} The inspiring ''Geometrie der Lage'' (1847) of [[Karl Georg Christian von Staudt]] provided Segre with another project. He encouraged [[Mario Pieri]] to make a translation, ''Geometria di Posizione'' (1889), while Segre composed a biographical sketch of von Staudt that was included in the publication. Segre also expanded algebraic geometry by consideration of [[multicomplex number]]s, in particular the [[bicomplex number]]s. Segre's 1892 contribution to [[Mathematische Annalen]] shows him extending the work of [[William Rowan Hamilton]] and [[William Kingdon Clifford]] on [[biquaternion]]s. But Segre was unaware of earlier study of tessarines that had anticipated his bicomplex numbers. In English, the best known work of Segre is an inspirational essay meant for Italian students, translated by J.W. Young in 1904.Corrado Segre (1904) "On some tendencies in geometric investigations", translated by J. W. Young, [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]] 10(9):442–68.{{cite journal | title = online article | mr = 1558145 | doi = 10.1090/S0002-9904-1904-01142-8 }} It provides guidance and encouragement to young people studying mathematics. In a 1926 memorial article, H.F. Baker called Segre the "father of" the [[Italian school of algebraic geometry]]. The 1912 article "Higher-dimensional Space" (''Mehr-dimensional Raume''Corrado Segre (1912) [http://gdz.sub.uni-goettingen.de/dms/load/img/?IDDOC=212904 Mehrdimensionale Räume]{{Dead link|date=April 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Enzyklopädie der mathematischen Wissenschaften'', weblink to [[University of Göttingen]]) for [[Klein's encyclopedia|''Enzyklopädie der mathematischen Wissenschaften'']] spanned 200 pages.{{cite journal | author = Hollcroft, T. R. | title = Review: ''Mehrdimensionale Räume'', by C. Segre | journal = Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. | year = 1936 | volume = 42 | issue = 1, Part 2 | pages = 5–6 | url = http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1936-42-01/S0002-9904-1936-06226-9/ | doi = 10.1090/s0002-9904-1936-06226-9 }} In admiration, Baker (1926) wrote and Coolidge (1927) reiterated :For completeness of detail, breadth of view, and generous recognition of the work of a host of other writers, this must remain for many years a monument of the comprehensiveness of the man. == Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == * {{Citation | last = Baker | first = H. [[standard monomial theory]] | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | prizes = [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award]], [[Padma Bhushan]], [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] | religion = | footnotes = }} '''C.S. Seshadri''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 29 February 1932{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=2012|title=C S Seshadri — A Glimpse of His Mathematical Personality|url=http://www.asiapacific-mathnews.com/02/0204/0017_0021.pdf|journal=Asia Pacific Mathematics Newsletter|volume=2|pages=17–21|via=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161210104338/http://www.asiapacific-mathnews.com/02/0204/0017_0021.pdf|archivedate=10 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}) is an eminent [[India]]n [[mathematician]]. He is the founder and ''Director-Emeritus'' of the [[Chennai Mathematical Institute]],{{cite web | url = http://www.cmi.ac.in/people/fac-profile.php?id=css | title = C.S. Seshadri's official profile an Chennai Mathematical Institute }} and is known for his work in [[algebraic geometry]]. The [[Seshadri constant]] is named after him. He is a recipient of the [[Padma Bhushan]] in 2009,[http://www.hindu.com/2009/01/26/stories/2009012659270100.htm Padma Bushan, 2009] the third highest civilian honor in the country.{{cite news| url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/prof.-c-s-seshadri-to-be-conferred-prestigious-rathindra-puraskar-from-visva-bharrati/389880/| title=Prof. C S Seshadri to be conferred prestigious Rathindra Puraskar from Visva Bharrati| work=BUSINESSWIRE INDIA| date= 24 November 2008 }} ==Degrees and posts== He received his B.A. (Hons) degree in Mathematics from [[Madras University]] in 1953 and was mentored by Fr. Racine and S Naryanan there.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/magazine/constant-mathematician/article5764243.ece|title=‘Constant’ Mathematician|last=RAMANI|first=HEMA IYER|newspaper=The Hindu|access-date=2016-12-10}} He completed his Ph.D. from [[Bombay University]] in 1958 under the supervision of [[K. S. Chandrasekharan]].{{MathGenealogy|id=75172|name=C. S. Seshadri}} He was elected Fellow of the [[Indian Academy of Sciences]] in 1971.Information of the Indian Academy of Sciences {{cite web|url=http://www.ias.ac.in/php/fell_detail.php3?name=Seshadri&intials=Conjeevaram&year=29-02-1932|title=Fellow Profile of Prof. C.S. Seshadri}} Seshadri worked in the School of Mathematics at [[TIFR]] in [[Bombay]] from 1953 to 1984 starting as a Research Scholar and rising to a senior professor. From 1984 to 1989, he worked in [[Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai|IMSc]] in [[Chennai]]. From 1989 to 2010, he worked as the founding director of the [[Chennai Mathematical Institute]]. He stepped down from his Directorship of the Chennai Mathematical Institute in December 2010. He continues to be a part of CMI as "Director-Emeritus" from 1 January 2011. ==Visiting professorships== * University of Paris, France * [[Harvard University]], Cambridge * [[UCLA]] * [[Brandeis University]] * University of Bonn, Bonn * [[Kyoto University]], Kyoto, Japan He has given talks at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians|ICM]]. ==Awards and fellowships== * Honorary degree, [[Université Pierre et Marie Curie]] (UPMC), Paris, 2013http://www.upmc.fr/fr/universite/histoire_et_personnalites/les_docteurs_honoris_causa/dhc2013/conjeevaram_srirangachari_seshadri.html * Honoris Causa, University of Hyderabad, India * [[Padma Bhushan]] * [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award]] * [[Srinivasa Ramanujan Medal]] from the [[Indian Academy of Sciences]] * Honorary D.Sc. from [[Banaras Hindu University]] * TWAS Science Award{{cite web|url=https://twas.org/article/twas-illycaffe-announce-2006-trieste-science-prize-winners|title=TWAS, illycaffè announce 2006 Trieste Science Prize winners}} * Fellow of IAS, INSA and a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] * Membership of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]]{{cite web|last=O'Leary|first=Maureen|title=72 New Members Chosen By Academy|url=http://www8.nationalacademies.org/onpinews/newsitem.aspx?RecordID=04272010|publisher=National Academy of Sciences|accessdate=22 September 2010}} * Fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]], 2012[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-07-18. ==Research work== Seshadri's main work is in [[algebraic geometry]]. His work with [[M S Narasimhan]] on unitary vector bundles and the [[Narasimhan–Seshadri theorem]] has influenced the field. His work on Geometric Invariant Theory and on Schubert varieties, in particular his introduction of [[standard monomial theory]], is widely recognized. Seshadri's contributions include the creation of the [[Chennai Mathematical Institute]], an institute for the study of [[mathematics]] in [[India]]. ==Publications== *{{cite journal |author1=[[M S Narasimhan|Narasimhan, M. "Premio reale" of the [[Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]] (1913) | nationality = [[Italia]]n | alma_mater = [[University of Turin|Università di Torino]], 1900 | doctoral_advisor = [[Corrado Segre]] | academic_advisors = [[Enrico d'Ovidio]], [[Federigo Enriques]], [[Eugenio Bertini]] | doctoral_students = [[Aldo Andreotti]], [[Enzo Martinelli]], [[Guido Zappa]] | notable_students = [[Luigi Fantappiè]], [[Gaetano Fichera]] | work_institutions = [[University of Turin|Università di Torino]], [[Università di Bologna]], [[University of Padua|Università di Padova]], [[University of Rome La Sapienza|Università di Roma]], [[Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica]] (now [[Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica Francesco Severi]]) | religion = [[Catholic]] }} [[File:Severi.jpeg|thumb|Francesco Severi (photo by Konrad Jacobs)]] '''Francesco Severi''' (13 April 1879 – 8 December 1961) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[mathematician]]. Severi was born in [[Arezzo]], [[Italy]]. He is famous for his contributions to [[algebraic geometry]] and the [[Several complex variables|theory of functions of several complex variables]]. He became the effective leader of the [[Italian school of algebraic geometry]]. Together with [[Federigo Enriques]], he won the ''[[Bordin prize]]'' from the [[French Academy of Sciences]]. He contributed in a major way to [[birational geometry]], the theory of [[algebraic surface]]s, in particular of the curves lying on them, the theory of [[moduli space]]s and the [[Several complex variables|theory of functions of several complex variables]]. He wrote prolifically, and some of his work has subsequently been shown to be not rigorous according to the then new standards set in particular by [[Oscar Zariski]] and [[David Mumford]]. At the personal level, according to {{harvtxt|Roth|1963}} he was easily offended, and he was involved in a number of controversies. Most notably, he was a staunch supporter of the Italian fascist regime of [[Benito Mussolini]] and was included on a committee of academics that was to conduct an anti-semitic purge of all scholarly societies and academic institutions.{{cite journal|doi=10.1090/noti881|title=A Fresh Look at Francesco Severi|journal=Notices of the American Mathematical Society|volume=59|issue=8|pages=1064|year=2012|last1=Goodstein|first1=Judith|author1-link=Judith R. Goodstein|last2=Babbitt|first2=Donald}} He died in [[Rome]] of [[cancer]]. == Selected publications == All the mathematical works of Francesco Severi, except all books, are collected in the six volumes of his "''Opere Matematiche''". *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = Sur une propriété fondamentale des fonctions analytiques de plusieurs variables |language = French |journal = [[Comptes rendus de l'Académie des sciences|Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des sciences]] |volume = 192 |date = 2 March 1931 |pages = 596–599 |url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k3145g/f596 |id = |mr = |zbl = 0001.14802 }}, available at [[Gallica]]. The paper containing the first proof of [[Morera's theorem]] for [[Several complex variables|holomorphic functions of several variables]]. *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = Risoluzione del problema generale di Dirichlet per le funzioni biarmoniche |trans-title=Solution of the general Dirichlet problem for biharmonic functions |journal = Rendiconti della [[Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]], Classe di Scienze Fisiche, Matematiche e Naturali |series = series 6, |volume = 13 |pages = 795–804 |year = 1931a |language = Italian |id = |jfm = 57.0393.01 |zbl = 0002.34202 }}. The announce of the solution of the [[Dirichlet problem]] for [[pluriharmonic function]]s for [[Domain (mathematical analysis)|domains]] with [[Real analytic function|real analytic]] [[Boundary (topology)|boundaries]]. *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = Una proprietà fondamentale dei campi di olomorfismo di una funzione analitica di una variabile reale e di una variabile complessa |trans-title=A fundamental property of the domain of holomorphy of an analytic function of one real variable and one complex variable |journal = Rendiconti della [[Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]], Classe di Scienze Fisiche, Matematiche e Naturali |series = series 6, |volume = 15 |pages = 487–490 |year = 1932 |language = Italian |id = |jfm = 58.0352.05 |zbl = 0004.40702 }}. In this paper Severi describes the "''[[passage from real to complex]]''" method he developed in order to deal with several problems in the [[Several complex variables|theory of functions of several complex variables]]. *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = A proposito d'un teorema di Hartogs |trans-title=About a theorem of Hartogs |journal = [[Commentarii Mathematici Helvetici]] |volume = 15 |issue = 1 |pages = 350–352 |year = 1942–1943 |language = Italian |url =http://www.e-periodica.ch/cntmng?pid=com-001:1942:15::27 |mr = 0010730 |zbl = 0028.15301 }}. In this work Severi gives his proof of the [[Hartogs' extension theorem]]. *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = Lezioni sulle funzioni analitiche di più variabili complesse – Tenute nel 1956–57 all'Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica in Roma |trans-title=Lectures on analytic functions of several complex variables – Lectured in 1956–57 at the Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica in Rome |language = Italian |place = Padova |publisher = CEDAM – Casa Editrice Dott. Antonio Milani |year = 1958 |pages = XIV+255 |url = |doi = |id = |zbl= 0094.28002 |isbn = }}. Notes from a course held by Francesco Severi at the [[Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica]] (which at present bears his name), containing appendices of Enzo Martinelli, Giovanni Battista Rizza and [[Mario Benedicty]]. *{{Citation |last = Severi |first = Francesco |author-link = |title = Opere matematiche. Memorie e note Vol. I |place = Roma |publisher = [[Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]] (distributed by Bardi Editore) |pages = XLII+491 |year = 1971 |language = Italian |url =http://mathematica.sns.it/media/volumi/477/Opere%20matematiche%20I.pdf |doi = |id = |mr = 0701703 |zbl = 0582.01027 |isbn = }} (available from the "''[http://mathematica.sns.it/ Edizione Nazionale Mathematica Italiana]''"). '''Igor Rostislavovich Shafarevich''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=small|ForMemRS}} ({{lang-ru|И́горь Ростисла́вович Шафаре́вич}}; 3 June 1923 – 19 February 2017) was a [[Russians|Russian]] [[mathematician]] who contributed to [[algebraic number theory]] and [[algebraic geometry]]. He wrote books and articles that criticize [[socialism]], and was an important [[dissident]] during the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] regime.

Shafarevich died on 19 February 2017 in [[Moscow]], at the age of 93.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://deita.ru/news/society/20.02.2017/5186530-ushel-iz-zhizni-matematik-i-filosof-igor-shafarevich/|script-title=ru:Ушел из жизни математик и философ Игорь Шафаревич|work=Deita.ru|date=20 February 2017|accessdate=20 February 2017|language=Russian}}</ref>

==Work in mathematics==
Shafarevich made fundamental contributions to several parts of [[mathematics]]
including [[algebraic number theory]], [[algebraic geometry]] and arithmetic algebraic geometry. In algebraic number theory the [[Shafarevich–Weil theorem]] extends the commutative reciprocity map to the case of [[Galois group]]s which are extensions of [[abelian group]]s by [[finite group]]s.
Shafarevich was the first to give a completely self-contained formula for the pairing which coincides with the wild [[Hilbert symbol]] on [[local field]]s, thus initiating an important branch of the study of explicit formulas in [[number theory]]. Another famous result is [[Shafarevich's theorem on solvable Galois groups]] giving the realization of every finite [[solvable group]] as a Galois group over the [[Rational number|rationals]]. Another fundamental result is the [[Golod–Shafarevich theorem]] on towers of [[unramified extension]]s of [[number field]]s.

Shafarevich and his school greatly contributed to the study of algebraic geometry of [[surface (mathematics)|surface]]s.
He initiated a [[Moscow]] seminar on [[classification of algebraic surfaces]] that updated around 1960 the treatment of [[birational geometry]], and was largely responsible for the early introduction of the [[scheme theory]] approach to algebraic geometry in the Soviet school. His investigation in arithmetic of [[elliptic curve]]s led him independently of [[John Tate]] to the introduction of the most mysterious group related
to [[elliptic curves]] over number fields, the [[Tate–Shafarevich group]] (usually called 'Sha', written 'Ш', his [[Cyrillic]] initial). He introduced the [[Grothendieck–Ogg–Shafarevich formula]] and the [[Néron–Ogg–Shafarevich criterion]]. He also formulated the [[Faltings's theorem|Shafarevich conjecture]] which stated the finiteness of the set of [[Abelian varieties]] over a number field having fixed dimension and prescribed set of primes of [[bad reduction]]. This conjecture was proved by [[Gerd Faltings]] as a step in his proof of the [[Mordell conjecture]].

Shafarevich was a student of [[Boris Delaunay]], and his students included [[Yuri Manin]], [[Alexey Parshin]], [[Igor Dolgachev]], [[Evgeny Golod]], [[Alexei Kostrikin]], Igor A. Kostrikin, [[Suren Arakelov]], [[G. V. Belyi]], Victor Abrashkin, Andrey N. Tyurin, and [[Victor Kolyvagin]]. He did major work in collaboration with [[Ilya Piatetski-Shapiro]] on [[K3 surface]]s. He was a member of the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] in the department of Mathematics, Physics and Earth Sciences.
In 1960 he was elected a Member of the [[German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leopoldina.org/en/members/list-of-members/member/8289/|title=List of Members|website=www.leopoldina.org|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> In 1981 he was elected as a foreign member of the [[Royal Society]].<ref name="Royal Society 2015">{{cite web | title=IgorShafarevich | website=Royal Society | date=1 September 2015 | url=https://royalsociety.org/people/igor-shafarevich-12257/ | access-date=10 October 2018}}</ref>

On his 80th birthday, Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] hailed his "fundamental research" in mathematics, and his creation of "a great science school known both in Russia and abroad".<ref>Putin congratulates prominent academician on 80th birthday TASS June 3, 2003</ref>

In 2017, Shafarevich was awarded the {{ill|Leonard Euler Gold Medal|ru|Золотая медаль имени Леонарда Эйлера|de|Leonhard-Euler-Goldmedaille}} by the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]].

==Political activities==
Shafarevich came into conflict with the Soviet authorities in the early 1950s, but was protected by [[Ivan Petrovsky]], the Rector of [[Moscow University]]. He belonged to a group of [[Pochvennichestvo]]-influenced dissidents who endorsed the [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christian]] tradition. Shafarevich published a book, ''The Socialist Phenomenon'' (French edition 1975, English edition 1980), which was cited by [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn|Solzhenitsyn]] in his 1978 address to [[Harvard University]].

In the 1970s Shafarevich, with [[Valery Chalidze]], [[Grigori Podyapolski]] and [[Andrei Tverdokhlebov]], became one of Sakharov's [[human rights]] investigators, and was consequently dismissed from Moscow University. Shafarevich opposed political interference in universities. The algebraic geometer [[Miles Reid]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} gives the example of Shafarevich asserting that plagiarism and poor work was being ignored in a doctorate obtained by a [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Communist Party]] functionary.

==''The Socialist Phenomenon''==
Shafarevich's book ''The Socialist Phenomenon'',<ref>The Socialist Phenomenon, by Igor Shafarevich. (1980) Translated by William Tjalsma. Foreword by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. 319 pp. New York: Harper & Row.</ref> which was published in the [[United States|US]] by [[Harper (publisher)|Harper & Row]] in 1980, analyzed numerous examples of socialism, from ancient times, through various medieval heresies, to a variety of modern thinkers and socialist states. From these examples he claimed that all the basic principles of socialist ideology derive from the urge to suppress [[individual]]ity. ''The Socialist Phenomenon'' consists of three major parts:<ref>The Socialist Phenomenon, by Igor Shafarevich. (1980). Contents.</ref>

# [[Chiliastic]] Socialism: Identifies socialist ideas amongst the ancient Greeks, especially [[Plato]], and in numerous medieval heretic groups such as the [[Cathars]], [[Brethren of the Free Spirit]], [[Taborites]], [[Anabaptists]], and various religious groups in the [[English Civil War]], and modern writers such as [[Thomas More]], [[Tommaso Campanella|Campanella]], and numerous [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] writers in 18th-century France.<ref>The Socialist Phenomenon, by Igor Shafarevich. (1980) pp.7–79</ref>
# State Socialism: Describes the socialism of the [[Incas]], the [[Jesuit]] state in [[Paraguay]], [[Mesopotamia]], [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]], and [[China]].<ref>The Socialist Phenomenon, by Igor Shafarevich. (1980) pp.80–131</ref>
# Analysis: Identifies three persistent abolition themes in socialism – the abolition of [[private property]], the abolition of the [[Nuclear family|family]], and the abolition of religion (mainly, but not exclusively [[Christianity]])<ref>The Socialist Phenomenon, by Igor Shafarevich. (1980) pp.132–192</ref>

Shafarevich argued that ancient socialism (such as Mesopotamia and Egypt) was not ideological, as an ideology socialism was a reaction to the emergence of individualism in the [[Axial Age]]. He compared [[Thomas More]]'s ([[Utopia]]) and [[Tommaso Campanella|Campanella]]'s ([[The City of the Sun|City of the Sun]]) visions with what is known about the [[Inca Empire]], and concluded that there are striking similarities. He claimed that we become persons through our relationship with God, and argued that socialism is essentially [[Nihilism|nihilistic]], unconsciously motivated by a death instinct. He concluded that we have the choice of either pursuing death or life.

==Religious views==

Shafarevich adhered to [[Russian Orthodox Christianity]] and incorporated the [[Neoplatonism|neo-Platonic]] views of [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] into his understanding of the relation of mathematics and religion.<ref>The Mathematical Experience, by Philip J. Davis and Reuben Hirsch. (1981) pp. 52–55</ref>

In his talk to the [[Göttingen Academy of Sciences]] upon receiving a prize, Shafarevich presented his view of the relationship between mathematics and religion. He notes the multiple discoveries in mathematics, such as that of [[non-Euclidean geometry]] to suggest that pure mathematics reflects an objective reality, not a set of conventional definitions or a formalism. He claimed that mathematics' growth in itself is not directed or organic. In order to have a unity and direction mathematics needs a goal. This goal can either be set by practical applications or by God as the source of the direction of development. Shafarevich opted for the latter, as pure mathematics is not in itself driven by practical applications.<ref>Ueber einige Tendenzen in der Entwicklung der Mathematik, Jarhrbuch der Akademie der Wissenschaften in Goettingen. (1973) pp. 31–42</ref>

==In Russian politics==

On 21 December 1991 he took part in the first congress of the [[Russian All-People's Union]] headed by [[Sergei Baburin]]. In October 1992 he became a member of the founding committee of the [[National Salvation Front (Russia)|National Salvation Front]]. In 1993 he was a candidate for the [[State Duma]] with [[Mikhail Astafyev]]'s [[Constitutional Democratic Party - Party of Popular Freedom]], but failed to get elected.

Shafarevich was a member of the editorial board of the magazine ''[[Nash Sovremennik]]'', and in 1991–1992 of the editorial board of ''Den'' of [[Alexander Prokhanov]] (which ceased in October 1993, and later reopened under the title ''[[Zavtra]]''). In 1994 he joined the "All-Russian National Right Wing Centre" chaired by [[Mikhail Astafyev]].

==Accusations of antisemitism==

Shafarevich's essay titled ''[[Russophobia]]'',<ref name="russophobiapdf">{{cite book|title=Russophobia|url=http://www.dtic.mil/get-tr-doc/pdf?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA335121|author=Shafarevich, Igor|date=Mar 1990|publisher=Joint Publications Research Service}}</ref> expanded into the book ''Three thousand year old mystery'' (Трехтысячелетняя загадка) resulted in accusations of [[antisemitism]].<ref name="books.google.com">{{Citation | url = https://books.google.com/?id=9-zvykby20kC&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=shafarevich+antisemitic | title = Abram Tertz and the poetics of crime | isbn = 978-0-300-06210-6 | author1 = Nepomnyashchy | first1 = Catharine Theimer | year = 1995 | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>Alexei Miller, [http://www.eurozine.com/articles/2002-05-24-miller-en.html The Communist Past in Post-Communist Russia], Eurozine, 2002-05-24.</ref><ref>Veljko Vujacic, [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3763/is_200403/ai_n9363937 Russian Intellectual Anti-Semitism in the Post-Communist Era], Canadian Slavonic Papers, Mar–Jun 2004.</ref> He completed the ''Russophobia'' essay in 1982 and it was initially circulated as ''[[samizdat]]''. In the USSR it was first officially published in 1989.

In the ''Russophobia'' essay he argued that great nations experience periods in their history when reformist elitist groups ('small nations') that have values that differ fundamentally from the values of the majority of the people, gain upper hand in the society. In Shafarevich's opinion, the role of such a 'small nation' in Russia was played by a small group of [[intelligentsiya]] dominated by [[Jews]]. They were full of hatred against traditional Russian way of life, playing an active role in the terrorist regimes of [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Joseph Stalin]].<ref name = srez/><ref>{{Citation | url = https://books.google.com/?id=a-dbI7B6Vs0C&pg=PA328&dq=shafarevich+russophobia#v=onepage&q=shafarevich%20russophobia&f=false | title = Reinventing Russia: Russian nationalism and the Soviet state, 1953–1991 | isbn = 978-0-674-00438-2 | author1 = Brudny | first1 = Yitzhak M | date = 2000-10-02 | postscript = .}}</ref>

Its publication led to a request by the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]] (NAS) to Shafarevich to resign his membership,<ref>Warren E. Leary, [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/29/us/alleging-bias-science-group-urges-russian-to-quit.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm "Alleging Bias, Science Group Urges Russian to Quit,"] ''The New York Times'', July 29, 1992.</ref> because the NAS charter prohibited stripping an existing membership.<ref>[[Joan Birman]], ''[http://www.the-scientist.com/article/display/16057/ AMS Condemns Russophobia]'', [[The Scientist (magazine)|The Scientist]], 1993, 7(8):12.</ref><ref>Semyon Reznik, [http://www.the-scientist.com/article/display/16054/ On Shafarevich And NAS: Tolerance Vs. Indifference]'', The Scientist, 1993, 7(8):11.</ref> In an open letter to the NAS, Shafarevich denied that ''Russophobia'' is antisemitic.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Igor R. Shafarevich |title=Russian Castigates NAS For Making 'Vague Accusations' |journal=[[The Scientist (magazine)|The Scientist]] |year=1992 |volume=6 |issue=24 |pages=11 |url=http://classic.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/12594/}}</ref> Shafarevich also noted that since NAS enlisted him without his request or knowledge, it is its internal matter to delist him as well. Nevertheless, when the United States [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invaded Iraq]], Shafarevich faxed his resignation.<ref>[http://balticworlds.com/legacy/ "The Steklov Legacy"], Ulf Persson, ''Baltic Worlds'', Pages 34–38, Vol 1, 2011</ref>

Accusations of anti-semitism have continued, involving Shafarevich's other publications.<ref>[http://www.alternativy.ru/ru/node/590 Шовинизм Шафаревича и Ко | Альтернативы]</ref> [[Semyon Reznik]] targets the ''Russophobia'' essay for alleged factual inaccuracies, that Shafarevich misassigned Jewish ethnicity to a number of non-Jewish individuals involved in the execution of [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]], perpetuating the false assertion that there was graffiti in [[Yiddish]] at the murder site, and suggested that Shafarevich's phrase "Nicholas II was [[Shooting of the Romanov family|shot]] specifically as the ''[[Tsar]]'', and this ritual act drew a line under an epoch in Russian history" – may be read as [[blood libel]].<ref name = srez>[http://www.vestnik.com/issues/2000/0118/win/reznik.htm Семён Резник. Кровавый навет в России]</ref> (An accusation which ignores the remainder of Shafarevich's sentence: "so it can only be compared with the execution of Charles I in England or of Louis XVI in France".)<ref name="russophobiapdf"/> [[Aron Katsenelinboigen]], wrote that Shafarevish's work "lives up to the best traditions of anti-Semitic propaganda".<ref>Aron J. Katsenelinboigen, ''The Soviet Union: Empire, Nation, and System'' (New Brunswick, New Jersey: 1990), page 176. http://aronkatsenelinboigen.net/Downloads/SovietUnion_empire_nation_system.htm</ref>

Later, Shafarevich expanded on his views in his book ''"Three thousand year old mystery"''. In this article Shafarevich further claimed that Jews effectively marginalize non-Jews to the point of exclusion in all types of intellectual endeavors. This work was published in Russian in 2002; an introductory section explains the relationship with the ''Russophobia'' essay, explaining that the essay developed from an Appendix to an intended work of wider scope which he started writing in ''samizdat''.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://shafarevich.voskres.ru/02.htm</ref>

The issue of Shafarevich's alleged anti-Semitism has been the subject of a 2009 doctoral thesis at the University of Helsinki, which was later turned into a book<ref name="berglund"></ref>, in which the author, Krista Berglund, concludes that Shafarevich's views have been misconstrued as anti-Semitic.

'''Nicholas Ian Shepherd-Barron''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 17 March 1955), is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[mathematician]] working in [[algebraic geometry]].  He is, since 2013, professor of mathematics at [[King's College London]],<ref>https://kclpure.kcl.ac.uk/portal/nicholas.shepherd-barron.html</ref> having moved there from his previous position at the [[University of Cambridge]]. Having been a Fellow for more than 20 years, Shepherd-Barron retains a life Fellowship of [[Trinity College, Cambridge]].<ref name=mathgene>{{MathGenealogy|id=74770}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dpmms.cam.ac.uk/~nisb/|title=Nicholas Shepherd-Barron home page}}</ref>

==Education==
He was a scholar of [[Winchester College]]. He obtained his B.A. at [[Jesus College, Cambridge]] in 1976, and studied for a Ph.D. at the [[University of Warwick]] under the supervision of [[Miles Reid]], graduating in 1981.<ref name=mathgene/><ref>{{Who's Who | surname = SHEPHERD-BARRON | othernames = Nicholas Ian | id = 151353 | volume = 2018 | edition = online}} {{subscription required}}</ref>

==Career and research==
He worked initially in the area of [[birational geometry]] and [[minimal model program|Mori theory]].  He was elected [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 2006.  He works on the classification of higher-dimensional varieties.
==Personal life==
He is the son of [[John Shepherd-Barron]], a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] inventor.{{fact|date=July 2016}}

'''Virgil Snyder''' (1869, [[Dixon, Iowa]] – 1950) was an [[United States|American]] mathematician, specializing in [[algebraic geometry]].

In 1886 Snyder matriculated at [[Iowa State University#History|Iowa State College]] and graduated with a bachelor's degree in 1889. He attended [[Cornell University]] as a graduate student from 1890 to 1892, leaving to study mathematics in Germany on an Erastus W. Brooks fellowship. In 1895 he received a doctorate from the [[University of Göttingen]] under [[Felix Klein]]. In 1895 Snyder returned to Cornell as an instructor, becoming an assistant professor in 1905 and a full professor in 1910. In 1938 he retired as professor emeritus, having supervised 39 doctoral students, 13 of whom were women.<ref>[http://www.math.cornell.edu/General/History/historyP6.html Cornell Math – Early History]</ref> Of these students, perhaps the most well-known is [[Clarence Lemuel Elisha Moore|C. L. E. Moore]]. Snyder served as president of the [[American Mathematical Society]] for a two-year term in 1927 and 1928.

He was an [[List of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|Invited Speaker]] of the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 1928 at [[Bologna]], in 1932 at [[Zurich]],<ref>{{cite journal|title=International Congress of Mathematicians, Zurich, 1932|author=Richardson, R. G. D.|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|volume=38|year=1932|pages=769–774|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1932-05491-X}} (See p. 772.)</ref> and in 1936 at [[Oslo]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=The international Congress in Oslo|author=Morse, Marston|authorlink=Marston Morse|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|volume=42|year=1936|pages=777–781|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1936-06421-9}} (See p. 780.)</ref>

Snyder did research on configurations of [[ruled surface]]s and [[Cremona group|Cremona]] and [[Birational geometry|birational transformations]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coble|first= Arthur B.|authorlink=Arthur Byron Coble|title=Virgil Snyder, 1869–1950|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1950|volume=56|issue=5|pages=468–471|mr=1565227|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1950-09413-0}}</ref>
