Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1916|volume=22|issue=7|pages=350–354|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1916-22-07/S0002-9904-1916-02797-2/S0002-9904-1916-02797-2.pdf|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1916-02797-2}}</ref>

He completed his [[Ph.D.]] at the [[University of Paris]] in 1979 under the supervision of [[Max Karoubi]] and [[Roger Godement]], with a dissertation titled ''K-Théorie des anneaux d'entiers de corps de nombres et cohomologie étale''. ==Awards and recognition== In 1979, he was awarded a [[CNRS Bronze Medal]]. He received the [[Prix J. Ponti]] in 1985 and the [[Prize Ampère]] in 1993.[http://www.academie-sciences.fr/academie/membre/SouleC_bio1008.pdf Notice biographique de Christophe Soulé, Membre de l’Académie des sciences (in French).] Since 2001, he is member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]].[http://www.academie-sciences.fr/academie/membre/Soule_Christophe.htm Membre de l'Académie des sciences (in French).] In 1983, he was [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] (ICM) in Warsaw.[http://www.mathunion.org/o/ICM/Speakers/SortedBySection.php International Mathematical Union (IMU): ICM Plenary and Invited Speakers since 1897] ==Publications== * Christophe Soulé, with the collaboration of [[Dan Abramovich]], Jean-François Burnol, and Jürg Kramer: ''Lectures on Arakelov Geometry.'' '''Karl-Otto Stöhr''' (born 9 May 1942) is a [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]] working on [[algebraic geometry]]. He is a titular researcher at the [[Instituto Nacional de Matemática Pura e Aplicada|IMPA]].<ref>[http://www.impa.br/opencms/en/pesquisa/pesquisa_pesquisadores/pesquisadores_karl_Otto_stohr/pesquisadores_karl_Otto_stohr.html IMPA]</ref>

Stöhr is a titular member of the [[Brazilian Academy of Sciences]] and has received [[Ordem Nacional do Mérito Científico|Brazil's National Order of Scientific Merit]].<ref>[http://www.abc.org.br/resultado.php3?codigo=Stohr Brazilian Academy of Sciences]</ref> He is also a member of the [[European Academy of Sciences]].<ref>[http://www.eurasc.org/members/members.asp?Cognome=s European Academy of Sciences]</ref>

He obtained his Ph.D. at the [[University of Bonn]] in 1967 under the guidance of [[Wolfgang Krull]] and [[Jacques Tits]].<ref name="MG">[http://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=50692 Mathematics Genealogy Project]</ref>

[[Arnaldo Garcia]] was a student of his.<ref name="MG" />

[[Cole Prize]] (2000) }} '''Andrei Suslin''' ({{lang-ru|Андре́й Алекса́ндрович Су́слин}}, sometimes transliterated '''Souslin''') was a [[Russia]]n [[mathematician]] who contributed to [[algebraic K-theory]] and its connections with [[algebraic geometry]]. He was a Trustee Chair and Professor of mathematics at [[Northwestern University]].[http://www.math.northwestern.edu/people/facultyProfiles/andrei.suslin.html Andrei Suslin, faculty profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610162004/http://www.math.northwestern.edu/people/facultyProfiles/andrei.suslin.html }}, Department of Mathematics, [[Northwestern University]] He was born on 27 December 1950 in [[St. Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. He received his PhD from [[Leningrad University]] in 1974; his thesis was titled ''Projective modules over polynomial rings''.{{MathGenealogy |id=25531}}. In 1976 he and [[Daniel Quillen]] independently proved [[Quillen–Suslin theorem|Serre's conjecture]] about the triviality of algebraic [[vector bundle]]s on [[affine space]]. In 1982 he and [[Alexander Merkurjev]] proved the famous [[Merkurjev–Suslin theorem]] on the norm residue homomorphism in Milnor K2-theory, with applications to the [[Brauer group]]. Suslin was an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 1978 and 1994, and he gave a plenary invited address at the Congress in 1986. He was awarded the [[Cole Prize|Frank Nelson Cole Prize]] in Algebra in 2000 by the [[American Mathematical Society]] for his work on [[motivic cohomology]].''2000 Cole Prize'' in ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society'', April 2000, vol. 47, no. 4, pp. 481–482, [http://www.ams.org/notices/200004/comm-cole.pdf] In 2010 special issues of ''Journal of K-theory''[http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayIssue?decade=2010&jid=KAG&volumeId=5&issueId=03&iid=7805173 Special Issues in honor of Andrei Suslin on his 60th birthday], ''Journal of K-theory'', doi=10.1017/is010006004jkt124 and of ''Documenta Mathematica'' {{cite web|url=https://www.math.uni-bielefeld.de/documenta/vol-suslin/vol-suslin.html |title=Extra volume of Documenta Mathematica (2010) in honour of A. Suslin|author=[[Ivan Fesenko|I. Fesenko]], E. Friedlander, [[Alexander Merkurjev|A. Merkurjev]], U. Rehmann (eds.) }} have been published in honour of his 60th birthday. He died on 10 July 2018.[https://nevnov.ru/574212-v-peterburge-ushel-iz-zhizni-izvestnyi-matematik-andrei-suslin В Петербурге ушел из жизни известный математик Андрей Суслин] {{ru icon}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100610162004/http://www.math.northwestern.edu/people/facultyProfiles/andrei.suslin.html Anfrei Suslin, faculty profile], Department of Mathematics, [[Northwestern University]] *{{IMO results |id=10055 }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Suslin, Andrei}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Russian mathematicians]] [[Category:Northwestern University faculty]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Institute for Advanced Study visiting scholars]] [[Category:International Mathematical Olympiad participants]]

He is known for [[Szpiro's conjecture]], which is related to the [[abc conjecture]]. ==Career== Szpiro attended [[Paris-Sud 11 University]] where he earned his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] under [[Pierre Samuel]] and [[Maurice Auslander]]. He then taught at Paris-Sud 11, [[Columbia University]], and the [[City University of New York]]. ==Awards== In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-08-05. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web| url=http://math.gc.cuny.edu/faculty/szpiro/People_Faculty_Szpiro.html|title= Website at CUNY}} *{{cite web| url=http://www.gc.cuny.edu/Faculty/Core-Bios/Lucien-Szpiro|title= Short biography}} *{{MathGenealogy |id=37670 }} *[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C11&q=author%3Alucien+author%3Aszpiro Search on author Lucien Szpiro] from [[Google Scholar]] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Szpiro, Lucien}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century mathematicians]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:City University of New York faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:Paris-Sud 11 University faculty]] [[Category:Number theorists]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] {{France-mathematician-stub}}

pages.title: Mina Teicher
Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas
pages.text:
'''Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas''' is a professor of Mathematics at [[Tufts University]] in [[Medford, Massachusetts|Medford]], [[Massachusetts]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://asegrad.tufts.edu/faculty/montserrat-teixidor-i-bigas|title=Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas {{!}} Tufts University - Graduate Programs|website=asegrad.tufts.edu|access-date=2019-05-07}}</ref>.  She specializes in [[Algebraic geometry]] especially [[Moduli space#Moduli of vector bundles|Moduli of Vector Bundles]] on Curves.<ref>[http://math.tufts.edu/people/facultyTeixidor.htm People Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas]</ref>

In 1986, she earned her PhD at the [[University of Barcelona]] in 1986 where she wrote her dissertation on the "[[geometry]][[Linear system|linear systems]] on [[Algebraic curve|algebraic curves]]" under the supervision of  Gerard Eryk Welters.<ref>[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=95650 Mathematics Genealogy Project]</ref> She worked in the Department of [[pure mathematics]] at the [[University of Liverpool]], UK, where in 1988 she wrote "The divisor of curves with a vanishing theta-null",<ref>[http://archive.numdam.org/ARCHIVE/CM/CM_1988__66_1/CM_1988__66_1_15_0/CM_1988__66_1_15_0.pdf The divisor of curves with a vanishing theta-null]</ref> which was published in [[Compositio Mathematica]].

In 1997, she proved [[Lange's conjecture]] for the generic curve, with [[Barbara Russo (mathematician)|Barbara Russo]], which states that "If <math>0<s\le n'(n-n')(g-1)</math>, then there exist stable vector bundles with <math>s_{n'}(E)=s</math>." They also clarified what happens in the interval <math>n'(n-n')(g-1)<s\le n'(n-n')g</math> using a degeneration argument to a reducible curve.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1997alg.geom..5019T On Lange's Conjecture]</ref>

She took up an appointment as an Associate Professor of Mathematics at Tufts University, and has been on the faculty of Tufts since 1989. She has been a reviewer for several journals, including the [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]], the [[Duke Mathematical Journal]], and the [[journal of algebraic geometry]]. She has held visiting positions at [[Brown University]] and the [[University of Cambridge]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/people/montserrat-teixidor-i-bigas|title=Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas|date=2012-03-16|website=Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University|language=en|access-date=2019-05-07}}</ref>.  She was also a co-organizer of the [[Clay Institute]]'s workgroup on Vector Bundles on Curves.<ref>[http://sites.tufts.edu/poincare/meet-the-team/montserrat-teixidor-i-bigas/ Montserrat Teixidor-i-Bigas]</ref> 

In 2004, she spent a year at [[Radcliffe College]], [[Harvard]] as a Vera M. Schuyler Fellow, devoting her time to study of "the interplay between the geometry of curves and the equations defining them."<ref>[http://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/people/montserrat-teixidor-i-bigas FELLOW Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas]</ref> 

==Selected publications==

* Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas, "Brill-Noether theory for vector bundles," Duke Math. J. Volume 62, Number 2 (1991), 385-400.<ref>[http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.dmj/1077296363 Brill-Noether theory for vector bundles, Duke Math. J. (1991)]</ref>
* Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas ''Curves in Grassmannians,'' Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 126 (1998), no. 6, 1597–1603<ref>[http://www.ams.org/journals/proc/1998-126-06/S0002-9939-98-04475-X/S0002-9939-98-04475-X.pdf Curves in Grassmannians, PAMS, 126 (1998), no. 6, 1597–1603]</ref>
* Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas "Green's conjecture for the generic <math>r</math>-gonal curve of genus <math>g\ge 3r-7</math>," Duke Math. J. 111 (2002), no. 2, 195–222.
* Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas ''Existence of coherent systems,''  Internat. J. Math. 19 (2008), no. 4, 449–454.<ref>[http://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/S0129167X08004777 Existence of coherent systems,  IJM, 19 (2008), no. 4, 449–454. ]</ref>
* Ivona Grzegorczyk, Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas, ''Brill-Noether theory for stable vector bundles,'' Moduli spaces and vector bundles, 29–50, London Math. Soc. Lecture Note Ser., 359, CUP, Cambridge (2009)<ref>[http://ebooks.cambridge.org/chapter.jsf?bid=CBO9781139107037&cid=CBO9781139107037A012, Moduli spaces and vector bundles, London Math. Soc. Lecture Note Ser., 359, Cambridge (2009)]</ref>
* Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas, ''Vector bundles on reducible curves and applications,'' Clay Mathematics Proceedings (2011) <ref>[http://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~osserman/math/montserrat-Clay.pdf Vector bundles on reducible curves and applications, Clay Mathematics Proceedings (2011)]</ref>
* Tawanda Gwena, Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas, ''Maps between moduli spaces of vector bundles and the base locus of the theta divisor''<ref>[https://arxiv.org/abs/0706.3953 Maps between moduli spaces of vector bundles and the base locus of the theta divisor]</ref>
* Brian Osserman, Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas ''Linked alternating forms and linked symplectic Grassmannians,''  Int. Math. Res. Not. IMRN 2014, no. 3, 720–744.<ref>[http://libra.msra.cn/Publication/27615582/linked-alternating-forms-and-linked-symplectic-grassmannians Linked alternating forms and linked symplectic Grassmannians, IMRN (2014), no. 3, 720–744.]</ref>

pages.text:
{{Infobox scientist
| name             = Richard Thomas
| image            = Richard Thomas, mathematician.jpg
| birth_name       = Richard Paul Winsley Thomas
| workplaces       = [[Imperial College London]]
| alma_mater       = [[University of Oxford]]
| thesis_title     = Gauge Theory on Calabi-Yau Manifolds<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=93812}}</ref>
| thesis_url       = http://www2.imperial.ac.uk/~rpwt/thesis.ps
| thesis_year      = 1997
| doctoral_advisor = [[Simon Donaldson]]
| fields           = [[Mathematics]]
| website          = {{URL|http://www2.imperial.ac.uk/~rpwt}}
| awards           = [[Whitehead Prize]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/mathematics/about/prizesandawards | title = Department of Mathematics Prizes and Awards | publisher = Imperial College London | accessdate = 22 January 2013}}</ref> {{small|(2004)}}
}}
'''Richard Paul Winsley Thomas''' FRS is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[mathematician]] working in several areas of [[geometry]]. He is a professor at [[Imperial College London]]. He studies [[moduli problem]]s in algebraic geometry, and ‘[[Mirror symmetry (string theory)|mirror symmetry]]’ — a phenomenon in pure mathematics predicted by [[string theory]] in theoretical physics.<ref>[https://royalsociety.org/people/richard-thomas-12414/ Richard Thomas FRS Biography]</ref>

==Education==
Thomas obtained his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] on [[gauge theory]] on [[Calabi–Yau manifold]]s in 1997 under the supervision of [[Simon Donaldson]] at the [[University of Oxford]]. Together with Donaldson, he defined the [[Donaldson–Thomas theory|Donaldson–Thomas invariants]] of Calabi–Yau [[3-fold]]s, now{{when|date=May 2019}} a major topic in geometry and the mathematics of string theory.

==Career and research==
Before joining Imperial College, he was member of the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]],<ref>https://www.ias.edu/scholars/richard-thomas</ref> and affiliated with [[Harvard University]] and the University of Oxford. He was made professor of pure mathematics in 2005.<ref>https://www.imperial.ac.uk/pictures/imperial_acad_proms_05.pdf</ref>

Thomas has made contributions to [[algebraic geometry]], [[differential Geometry]], and [[symplectic geometry]]. His doctoral thesis, which introduced the invariants that later became known as Donaldson-Thomas invariants, was published in the [[Journal of Differential Geometry]] as `A holomorphic Casson invariant for Calabi-Yau 3-folds, and bundles on K3 fibrations'.<ref>https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.jdg/1214341649</ref> Motivated by [[homological mirror symmetry]], he produced [[braid group]] actions on [[derived categories]] of [[coherent sheaves]] in joint work with [[Paul Seidel]].<ref>https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.dmj/1091737124</ref> With [[Shing-Tung Yau]] he formulated a conjecture (now known as the Thomas–Yau conjecture) concerning the existence of a special Lagrangian in the Hamiltonian deformation class of a fixed [[Lagrangian submanifold]] of a [[Calabi–Yau manifold]].<ref>https://www.intlpress.com/site/pub/files/_fulltext/journals/cag/2002/0010/0005/CAG-2002-0010-0005-a008.pdf</ref> Together with [[Rahul Pandharipande]] he formulated a refinement of the Donaldson–Thomas invariants for the special case of curve counting, the Pandharipande–Thomas (PT) stable pair invariants.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1007/s00222-009-0203-9|title = Curve counting via stable pairs in the derived category|journal = Inventiones Mathematicae|volume = 178|issue = 2|pages = 407–447|year = 2009|last1 = Pandharipande|first1 = R|last2 = Thomas|first2 = R. P|arxiv = 0707.2348}}</ref> With Martijn Kool and Vivek Shende, he used the PT invariants to prove the [[Lothar Göttsche|Göttsche]] conjecture — a classical algebro-geometric problem going back more than a century.<ref>[https://arxiv.org/abs/1010.3211 A short proof of the Göttsche conjecture]</ref>  With Davesh Maulik and Pandharipande he proved the Katz–Klemm–Vafa (KKV) conjecture,<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1112/jtopol/jtq030|title = Curves on K 3 surfaces and modular forms|journal = Journal of Topology|volume = 3|issue = 4|pages = 937–996|year = 2010|last1 = Maulik|first1 = D|last2 = Pandharipande|first2 = R|last3 = Thomas|first3 = R. P|citeseerx = 10.1.1.756.7349}}</ref> establishing links between the [[Gromov-Witten theory]] of [[K3 surface]]s and [[modular forms]]. His collaboration with [[Daniel Huybrechts]] led to contributions to the deformation theory of complexes.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1007/s00208-009-0397-6|title = Deformation-obstruction theory for complexes via Atiyah and Kodaira–Spencer classes|journal = Mathematische Annalen|volume = 346|issue = 3|pages = 545–569|year = 2009|last1 = Huybrechts|first1 = Daniel|last2 = Thomas|first2 = Richard P|arxiv = 0805.3527}}</ref> With Nick Addington he established a compatibility result for two rationality conjectures on cubic fourfolds.<ref>https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.dmj/1404824304</ref>

He coauthored a book on mirror symmetry.<ref>http://www.claymath.org/library/monographs/cmim-1.pdf</ref> Thomas also wrote expository notes on derived categories,<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = math/0001045|last1 = Thomas|first1 = R. P|title = Derived categories for the working mathematician|journal = Proceedings of the Winter School on Mirror Symmetry, Vector Bundles and Lagrangian Cycles, Harvard, January|volume = 1999|issue = 2001|year = 2000}}</ref> curve counting,<ref>{{Cite book |arxiv = 1111.1552|last1 = Thomas|first1 = R. P|last2 = Thomas|first2 = R. P|title = Moduli Spaces|pages = 282–333|year = 2011|doi = 10.1017/CBO9781107279544.007|isbn = 9781107279544}}</ref> and homological projective duality.<ref>{{Cite arxiv |eprint = 1512.08985|last1 = Thomas|first1 = R. P|title = Notes on HPD|class = math.AG|year = 2015}}</ref> He appeared in the documentary film 'Thinking space' by Heidi Morstang.<ref>https://www.lms.ac.uk/library/frames-of-mind</ref> Thomas has played an important part in promoting geometry in the UK, encouraging younger mathematicians,<ref>https://academic.oup.com/blms/article-abstract/37/3/468/326357?redirectedFrom=fulltext</ref> and in bringing more geometry to Imperial college: "[...] There was little geometry in Imperial then, but now, thanks largely to the drive of my colleague Richard Thomas, we have one of the main centres for research in this area." - [[Simon Donaldson]]<ref>http://www.shawprize.org/en/shaw.php?tmp=3&twoid=12&threeid=41&fourid=22&fiveid=11</ref>

==Awards and honours==
In 2004, Thomas was awarded the [[London Mathematical Society]]'s [[Whitehead Prize]] and the [[Philip Leverhulme Prize]], in 2010 the [[Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit Award]]. From the Whitehead prize citation:

"Thomas has made seminal contributions across an unusually broad range of topics.
Much of his work is related to mirror symmetry and Calabi–Yau geometry, and thus
has an important bearing on exciting contemporary interactions with mathematical
physics. [...] This involved the combination of deep, original insights and
sophisticated technical proofs that is characteristic of Thomas’s work."<ref>https://academic.oup.com/blms/article-abstract/37/3/468/326357?redirectedFrom=fulltext</ref>

In 2010 he also was invited speaker for the algebraic geometry section at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Hyderabad]], where he delivered a lecture on mirror symmetry.<ref>https://www.mathunion.org/icm-plenary-and-invited-speakers?combine=&page=14&order=field_speakers_congress_year&sort=desc</ref> Thomas was elected a [[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 2015|Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2015]].<ref>[https://royalsociety.org/people/richard-thomas-12414/ FRS announcement]</ref><ref>[http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/newsandeventspggrp/imperialcollege/newssummary/news_5-5-2015-15-46-48 Professors in Mathematics and Chemistry honoured with Royal Society Fellowships]</ref>
His contributions to algebraic geometry led to his election to the 2018 class of [[fellow]]s of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://ams.org/profession/ams-fellows/new-fellows|title=2018 Class of the Fellows of the AMS|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|accessdate=2017-11-03}}</ref>

Prix Franco-Britannique {{small|(2001)}} |religion = |signature = |footnotes = | website = {{Plainlist| * {{URL|http://burttotaro.wordpress.com}} * {{URL|http://www.math.ucla.edu/~totaro/}}}}}} '''Burt James Totaro''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (b. 1967), is an American [[mathematician]], currently a Professor at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], specializing in [[algebraic geometry]] and [[algebraic topology]]. == Education and early life == Totaro participated in the [[Study of Mathematically Precocious Youth]] while in grade school. After spending two years at [[Moorestown High School]] in [[New Jersey]], he enrolled at [[Princeton University]] at the age of thirteen.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AxNbAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA54|title= Princeton Alumni Weekly}} He graduated in 1984 and went on to graduate school at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], receiving his [[Ph.D.]] in 1989.{{MathGenealogy|32036}} ==Career and research== Since 2009, he has been one of three managing editors of the journal ''[[Compositio Mathematica]]'';{{cite web|url=http://www.compositio.nl/editors.html|title=Editorial Board of Compositio Mathematica}} he is also on the editorial boards of [[Forum of Mathematics| Forum of Mathematics, Pi and Sigma]], the [[Journal of the American Mathematical Society]], and the [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]]. In 2012, he became a Professor in the UCLA Department of Mathematics.{{cite web | url=http://www.math.ucla.edu/sites/default/files/newsletter/nl2012.pdf | title = UCLA Department of Mathematics newsletter}} Totaro's work is influenced by the [[Hodge conjecture]], and is based on the connections and application of topology to algebraic geometry. His work has applications in a number of diverse areas of mathematics, from [[representation theory]] to [[Lie theory]] and [[group cohomology]].[http://www.cambridgenetwork.co.uk/news/article/default.aspx?objid=59488 Cambridge academics elected as Fellows of the Royal Society] ===Selected works=== *{{cite journal|last=Totaro|first= Burt|title = Configuration spaces of algebraic varieties|journal=[[Topology (journal)|Topology]] | volume= 35 |year=1996|issue= 4| pages=1057–1067|doi=10.1016/0040-9383(95)00058-5|mr=1404924}} *{{Cite book |last=Totaro |first=Burt |year=2014 |title=Group Cohomology and Algebraic Cycles |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-1-107-01577-7 |url=https://www.cambridge.org/9781107015777 }} ==Recognition== In 2000, he was elected [[Lowndean Professor of Astronomy and Geometry]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. In the same year, he was awarded the [[Whitehead Prize]] by the [[London Mathematical Society]].[http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/citations00/totaro.html Citation for Burt Totaro] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012060504/http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/citations00/totaro.html |date=October 12, 2007 }} In 2009, Totaro was elected [[Fellow of the Royal Society]].{{cite web | url = http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/news/dp/2009051501 | title = Cambridge academics elected as Fellows of the Royal Society | publisher = Cambridge University news | date = 2009-05-16 | accessdate = 2009-05-16 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090521091552/http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/news/dp/2009051501 | archive-date = 2009-05-21 | dead-url = yes }} He was included in the 2019 class of fellows of the [[American Mathematical Society]] "for contributions to algebraic geometry, Lie theory and cohomology and their connections and for service to the profession".{{citation|url=https://www.ams.org/profession/ams-fellows/new-fellows|title=2019 Class of the Fellows of the AMS|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|accessdate=2018-11-07}} == References == {{reflist|35em}} {{FRS 2009}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Totaro, Burt}} [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:Whitehead Prize winners]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:Cambridge mathematicians]] [[Category:Lowndean Professors of Astronomy and Geometry]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Topologists]] {{US-mathematician-stub}}

[[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]] | alma_mater = [[University of Paris-Sud]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Lucien Szpiro]] | awards = Elie Cartan Prize (2006) }} '''Emmanuel Ullmo''' (born 25 June 1965) is a French mathematician, specialised in [[algebraic geometry]]. Since 2013 he has served as director of the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques|Institut des Hautes Études scientifiques]]. == Biography == He wrote his thesis under [[Lucien Szpiro]] at the [[University of Paris-Sud]] in 1992, where he was appointed professor in 2001.{{MathGenealogy|id=56585|56585|title=Emmanuel Ullmo|Emmanuel Ullmo}} He also held temporary positions at [[Instituto Nacional de Matemática Pura e Aplicada|IMPA]] ([[Brazil]]) for 18 months, then two years at [[Princeton University]], and six months at the [[University of Tsinghua]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.ihes.fr/en/professeur/emmanuel-ullmo-2/|title=Biography at the IHES|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} He was editor of the journal ''[[Inventiones Mathematicae|Inventiones mathematicae]]'' between 2007 and 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://www.springer.com/mathematics/journal/222/PSE?detailsPage=editorialBoard|title=Page of Inv. Math. on springer.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 2013, following the retirement of [[Jean-Pierre Bourguignon]], he became the 5th director of the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques|IHÉS]]. === Awards === He was an invited speaker at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] at [[Beijing]] in 2002. Between 2003 and 2008 he was a junior fellow at the [[Institut de France]]. He received the Elie Cartan Prize of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] in 2006 for a proof of the [[Bogomolov conjecture]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.academie-sciences.fr/archivage_site/activite/prix/laureat_cartan.pdf|title=Laureates of the Elie Cartan Prize|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}Kazuhiko Yamaki, "[[arxiv:1603.09083v2|Survey on the geometric Bogomolov conjecture]]", talk at "Non-archimedean analytic Geometry: Theory and Practice" (Papeete, 24–28 August 2015). == References == {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ullmo, Emmanuel}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Paris-Sud 11 University faculty]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]]

Vakil''' (born February 22, 1970) is a Canadian-American mathematician working in [[algebraic geometry]]. ==Education and career== Vakil attended high school at [[Martingrove Collegiate Institute]] in [[Etobicoke]], [[Ontario]], where he won several mathematical contests and olympiads.{{cite web|title=CMO Winners sorted by school by rank|url=http://cms.math.ca/Competitions/OMC/results/winschool|publisher=Canadian Mathematical Society|accessdate=18 August 2016}} After earning a BSc and MSc from the [[University of Toronto]] in 1992, he completed a Ph.D. in mathematics at [[Harvard University]] in 1997 under [[Joseph Daniel Harris|Joe Harris]].[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=18790 Mathematics genealogy] He has since been an instructor at both [[Princeton University]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]. Since the fall of 2001, he has taught at [[Stanford University]],[http://math.stanford.edu/directory/faculty.html Stanford mathematics faculty] becoming a full professor in 2007. ==Contributions== Vakil is an [[algebraic geometry|algebraic geometer]] and his research work spans over [[enumerative geometry]], [[topology]], [[Gromov–Witten theory]], and classical algebraic geometry. He has solved several old problems in [[Schubert calculus]]. Among other results, he proved that all Schubert problems are enumerative over the [[real number]]s, a result that resolves an issue mathematicians have worked on for at least two decades. ==Awards and honors== Vakil has received many awards, including an [[National Science Foundation|NSF]] Career Fellowship, a [[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation|Sloan]] Research Fellowship, an [[American Mathematical Society]] Centennial Fellowship, a G. de B. Robinson Prize for the best paper published in the [[Canadian Mathematical Society|Canadian Journal of Mathematics and the Canadian Mathematical Bulletin]], and the André-Aisenstadt Prize from the [[Centre de Recherches Mathématiques]] at the [[Université de Montréal]] (2005). In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-08-28. ==Mathematics contests== He was a member of the Canadian team in three [[International Mathematical Olympiad]]s, winning silver, gold (perfect score), gold in 1986, 1987, and 1988 respectively. He was also the fourth person to be a four-time [[William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition|Putnam]] Fellow in the history of the contest. Also, he has been the coordinator of weekly Putnam preparation seminars at Stanford.http://articles.sfgate.com/2006-12-02/bay-area/17323902_1_college-math-putnam-math-competitions ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://math.stanford.edu/~vakil/ Ravi Vakil's Home Page] * {{MathGenealogy |id=18790}} * {{IMO results |id=1576 }} {{Chauvenet Prize recipients}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vakil, Ravi}} [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University faculty]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Canadian mathematicians]] [[Category:People from Etobicoke]] [[Category:Putnam Fellows]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian people of Indian descent]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:International Mathematical Olympiad participants]]

'''Giuseppe Veronese''' (7 May 1854 – 17 July 1917) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[mathematician]]. He was born in [[Chioggia]], near [[Venice]].

==Education==
Veronese earned his [[laurea]] in mathematics from the Istituto Tecnico di Venezia in 1872.

==Work==
Although Veronese's work was severely criticised as unsound by [[Giuseppe Peano|Peano]], he is now recognised as having priority on many ideas that have since become parts of [[transfinite number]]s and [[model theory]], and as one of the respected authorities of the time, his work served to focus Peano and others on the need for greater rigor.

He is particularly noted for his hypothesis of relative continuity which was the foundation for his development of the first non-[[Archimedean property|Archimedean]] [[linear]] [[Continuum (set theory)|continuum]].

Veronese produced several significant monographs. The most famous appeared in 1891, ''Fondamenti di geometria a più dimensioni e a più specie di unità rettilinee esposti in forma elementare'', normally referred to as ''Fondamenti di geometria'' to distinguish it from Veronese' other works also styled ''Fondamenti''. It was this work that was most severely criticised by both Peano and [[Georg Cantor|Cantor]], however [[Tullio Levi-Civita|Levi-Civita]] described it as ''masterful'' and [[David Hilbert|Hilbert]] as ''profound''.

pages.title: Oleg Viro
pages.text:
[[File:Oleg Viro.jpg|thumb|Oleg Viro in 2008 at the [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach]]]]
'''Oleg Yanovich Viro''' ({{lang-ru|Олег Янович Виро}}) (b. 13 May 1948, [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]]) is a [[Russia]]n [[mathematician]] in the fields of [[topology]] and [[algebraic geometry]], most notably [[real algebraic geometry]], [[tropical geometry]] and [[knot theory]].

==Contributions==
{{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2019}}
Viro developed a "patchworking" technique in algebraic geometry, which allows real [[algebraic variety|algebraic varieties]] to be constructed by a sort of "cut and paste" method. Using this technique, Viro was able to complete the [[homotopy|isotopy]] classification of non-singular plane projective curves of degree 7. The patchworking technique was one of the fundamental ideas which motivated the development of [[tropical geometry]]. In [[topology]], Viro is most known for his joint work with [[Vladimir Turaev]], in which the Turaev-Viro invariants and related [[topological quantum field theory]] notions were introduced.

==Education and career==
Viro studied at the [[Leningrad State University]] where he received Ph.D. degree in 1974; his advisor was [[Vladimir Rokhlin (Soviet mathematician)|Vladimir Rokhlin]].<ref>{{MathGenealogy |id=49906}}</ref> Viro taught from 1973 until 1991 at [[Leningrad State University]]. Since 1986 he is a member of the [[St. Petersburg Department of Steklov Institute of Mathematics of Russian Academy of Sciences|Saint Petersburg Department]] of the [[Steklov Institute of Mathematics]]. In 1992-1997, Viro was a F. B. Jones chair professor in Topology at the [[University of California, Riverside]].

In 1994-2007 he was a professor at [[Uppsala University]], [[Sweden]]. On 8 February 2007, Viro and his colleague [[Burglind Juhl-Jöricke]] were forced to resign from the university.<ref> [http://chronicle.com/weekly/v53/i38/38a04901.htm Swedish University, Alleging Culture Clash, Forces Out 2 Tenured Foreign Professors,] [[Chronicle of Higher Education]], Volume 53, Issue 38, Page A49; May 25, 2007.</ref> There had been a history of conflict at the Mathematics Institute, with allegations of disagreeable behavior by several parties in the conflict.<ref> Some Uppsala University administrators defended the forced resignations in an open letter:
*[http://www2.unt.se/avd/1,1826,MC=2-AV_ID=623641,00.html?from=read_more Article by the Faculty Dean and by some Departmental Chairpersons] [[Uppsala Nya Tidning]] June 17, 2007.</ref> A number of Swedish, European and American mathematicians protested the manner in which the two Professors of Mathematics were forced to resign. These protests include the following:
*an open letter by [[Lennart Carleson]], former president of the [[International Mathematical Union]],
*a letter by [[Ari Laptev]], current president of the [[European Mathematical Society]], and
*a letter from [[M. Salah Baouendi]], [[Arthur Jaffe]], [[Joel Lebowitz]], [[Elliott H. Lieb]] and [[Nicolai Reshetikhin]].<ref> ''[http://www.emis.de/press.html Two mathematicians forced to resign at Uppsala University, Sweden],'' a collection of letters and articles, hosted by the European Mathematical Society.</ref><ref>[http://www.pdmi.ras.ru/~olegviro/index.html Oleg Viro's webpage]</ref>

As of 2009, Viro is a senior researcher at the St. Petersburg Department of the Steklov Institute of Mathematics, and a Professor at [[Stony Brook University]].

==Awards and honors==
Viro was an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 1983 ([[Warsaw]]) and the [[European Congress of Mathematicians]] in 2000 ([[Barcelona]]). He is a recipient of the Goran Gustafsson Prize (1997) from the Swedish government.

In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-08-29.</ref>

pages.title: Vladimir Voevodsky
pages.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Vladimir Voevodsky | image = VladimirVoevodsky.jpg | image_size = | caption = Voevodsky in 2011 |birth_name=Vladimir Alexandrovich Voevodsky | birth_date = {{birth date|1966|06|04|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|2017|09|30|1966|06|04|df=y}}}} | death_place =[[Princeton, New Jersey]], United States | nationality = [[Russia]]n, [[America]]n | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = [[Institute for Advanced Study]] | alma_mater = [[Moscow State University]]
[[Harvard University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[David Kazhdan]] | doctoral_students = | known_for = | awards = [[Fields Medal]] (2002) }} '''Vladimir Alexandrovich Voevodsky''' ({{IPAc-en|v|ɔj|ɛ|ˈ|v|ɒ|d|s|k|i}}; {{lang-ru|Влади́мир Алекса́ндрович Воево́дский}}, 4 June 1966 – 30 September 2017) was a [[Russia]]n-[[America]]n [[mathematician]]. His work in developing a [[homotopy theory]] for [[algebraic varieties]] and formulating [[motivic cohomology]] led to the award of a [[Fields Medal]] in 2002. He is also known for the proof of the [[Milnor conjecture]] and motivic [[Bloch-Kato conjectures]] and for the [[univalent foundations]] of mathematics and [[homotopy type theory]]. == Early life and education == Vladimir Voevodsky's father, Aleksander Voevodsky, was head of the Laboratory of High Energy Leptons in the Institute for Nuclear Research at the Russian Academy of Sciences. His mother Tatyana was a chemist. Voevodsky attended [[Moscow State University]] for a while, but was forced to leave without a diploma for refusing to attend classes and failing academically. He received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in mathematics from [[Harvard University]] in 1992 after being recommended without ever applying, following several independent publications; he was advised there by [[David Kazhdan]]. While he was a first year undergraduate, he was given a copy of [[Esquisse d'un Programme]] (submitted a few months earlier by [[Alexander Grothendieck]] to [[CNRS]]) by his advisor George Shabat. He learned the [[French language]] "with the sole purpose of being able to read this text" and started his research on some of the themes mentioned there.See the autobiographical story in {{cite web|last1=Voevodsky|first1=Vladimir|title=Univalent Foundations|url=http://www.math.ias.edu/~vladimir/Site3/Univalent_Foundations_files/2014_IAS.pdf|publisher=[[Institute for Advanced Study]]}} == Work == Voevodsky's work was in the intersection of [[algebraic geometry]] with [[algebraic topology]]. Along with [[Fabien Morel]], Voevodsky introduced a [[homotopy theory]] for [[Scheme (mathematics)|schemes]]. He also formulated what is now believed to be the correct form of [[motivic cohomology]], and used this new tool to prove [[Milnor's conjecture]] relating the [[Milnor]] [[K-theory]] of a [[field (mathematics)|field]] to its [[étale cohomology]]. For the above, he received the [[Fields Medal]] at the 24th [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] held in [[Beijing]], [[China]].The second medal at the same congress was received by [[Laurent Lafforgue]] In 1998 he gave a plenary lecture (''A1-Homotopy Theory'') at the International Congress of Mathematicians in [[Berlin]].{{cite book|author=Voevodsky, Vladimir|chapter=A1-homotopy theory|title=''In:'' Proceedings of the International Congress of Mathematicians|volume=vol. 1|pages=579–604|year=1998|chapter-url=http://www.math.ias.edu/vladimir/files/A1_homotopy_ICM_1998_Berlin_published.pdf}} He coauthored (with [[Andrei Suslin]] and [[Eric M. Friedlander]]) ''Cycles, Transfers and Motivic Homology Theories'', which develops the theory of motivic cohomology in some detail. From 2002, Voevodsky was a professor at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]]. In January 2009, at an anniversary conference in honor of [[Alexander Grothendieck]], held at the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]], Voevodsky announced a proof of the full [[Bloch-Kato conjectures]]. In 2009, he constructed the univalent model of [[Martin-Löf type theory]] in [[simplicial set]]s. This led to important advances in type theory and in the development of new [[Univalent foundations]] of mathematics that Voevodsky worked on in his final years. He worked on a [[Coq]] library ''UniMath'' using univalent ideas.{{Citation|title=UniMath: This coq library aims to formalize a substantial body of mathematics using the univalent point of view|date=2017-10-07|url=https://github.com/UniMath/UniMath|publisher=Univalent Mathematics|accessdate=2017-10-07}} In April 2016, the [[University of Gothenburg]] awarded an honorary doctorate to Voevodsky.{{cite web|url=http://itufak.gu.se/english/current/news/news-detail/fields-medalist-vladimir-voevodsky-new-honorary-doctor-at-the-it-faculty.cid1380718|title=Fields medalist Vladimir Voevodsky new honorary doctor at the IT Faculty}} ==Death and legacy == Voevodsky died on 30 September 2017 at his home in Princeton, from an [[aneurysm]].{{cite newspaper|author=Rehmeyer, Julie|date=6 October 2017|title=Vladimir Voevodsky, Revolutionary Mathematician, Dies at 51|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/06/obituaries/vladimir-voevodsky-revolutionary-mathematician-dies-at-51.html}}{{cite web | title=IAS: Vladimir Voevodsky, Fields Medalist, Dies at 51|url=https://www.ias.edu/news/2017/vladimir-voevodsky| accessdate=2017-09-30}} He is survived by daughters Diana Yasmine Voevodsky and Natalia Dalia Shalaby. ==Selected works== * Voevodsky, Vladimir, Suslin, Andrei, and Friedlander, Eric M. (2000). [https://books.google.com/books/about/Cycles_Transfers_and_Motivic_Homology_Th.html?id=WiDHDgAAQBAJ''Cycles, transfers, and motivic homology theories'']. Annals of Mathematics Studies Vol. 143. Princeton University Press.{{cite journal|author=Weibel, Charles A.|title=Review of ''Cycles, transfers, and motivic homology theories'' by Vladimir Voevodsky, Andrei Muslin, and Eric M. Friedlander|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|year=2002|volume=39|issue=1|pages=137–143|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/2002-39-01/S0273-0979-01-00930-2/S0273-0979-01-00930-2.pdf|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-01-00930-2}} * Mazza, Carlo, Voevodsky, Vladimir and Weibel, Charles A. [[Shaw Prize]] (2017) }} '''Claire Voisin''' (born 4 March 1962) is a French mathematician known for her work in [[algebraic geometry]]. She is the Director of research at [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique]] at the [[Institut de mathématiques de Jussieu – Paris Rive Gauche]], a member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] and the chair of [[Algebraic geometry]] at the [[Collège de France]]. ==Work== She is noted for her work in [[algebraic geometry]] particularly as it pertains to variations of [[Hodge theory#Hodge structures|Hodge structures]] and [[mirror symmetry (string theory)|mirror symmetry]], and has written several books on [[Hodge theory]]. In 2002 Voisin proved that the generalization of the [[Hodge conjecture]] for compact [[Kähler manifolds|Kähler varieties]] is false.[http://imrn.oxfordjournals.org/content/2002/20/1057.short A counterexample to the Hodge conjecture extended to Kähler varieties] The [[Hodge conjecture]] is one of the seven [[Clay Mathematics Institute]] [[Millennium Prize Problems]] which were selected in 2000, each having a prize of one million US dollars. Voisin won the [[European Mathematical Society|European Mathematical Society Prize ]] in 1992, and the Servant Prize awarded by the Academy of Sciences in 1996.[http://www.math.polytechnique.fr/~voisin/Articlesweb/noticevoisin.pdf Prix Servant décerné par l’Académie des Sciences (1996)] She received the [[Sophie Germain#Sophie Germain Prize|Sophie Germain Prize]] in 2003[http://www.upmc.fr/fr/recherche/talents_et_decouvertes/prix_et_distinctions/2003/claire_voisin_recoit_le_prix_sophie_germain_2003_de_l_academie_des_sciences.html Claire Voisin awarded the 2003 Sophie Germain Academy of Sciences] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122040143/http://www.upmc.fr/fr/recherche/talents_et_decouvertes/prix_et_distinctions/2003/claire_voisin_recoit_le_prix_sophie_germain_2003_de_l_academie_des_sciences.html |date=2013-01-22 }} and the [[Clay Research Award]] in 2008 for her disproof of the [[Kunihiko Kodaira|Kodaira]] conjecture on deformations of compact [[Kähler manifold|Kähler]] [[manifolds]].[http://www.claymath.org/research Clay Research Award] In 2007 she was awarded the [[Ruth Lyttle Satter Prize in Mathematics]] for, in addition to her work on the Kodaira conjecture, solving the generic case of [[Clifford's theorem on special divisors#Green's Conjecture|Green's conjecture]] on the [[syzygy (mathematics)|syzygies]] of the canonical embedding of an algebraic curve.[http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/prizes.htm#satter Satter Prize] The ''generic'' case of Green's conjecture had received considerable attention from algebraic geometers for over two decades prior to its resolution by Voisin (the full conjecture for ''arbitrary'' curves is still partially open). [[File:ClaireVoisinBMC2014.JPG|left|thumb|Voisin at [[Queen Mary University of London]] in 2014]] She was an invited speaker at the 1994 [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Zürich]] in the section 'Algebraic Geometry', and she was also invited as a plenary speaker at the 2010 International Congress of Mathematicians in [[Hyderabad]].[http://www.icm2010.org.in/ ''International Congress of Mathematicians 2010''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208184251/http://www.icm2010.org.in/ |date=2010-02-08 }} In 2014 she was elected to the [[Academia Europaea]].{{citation|publisher=[[Academia Europaea]]|title=Member profile: Claire Voisin|url=http://www.ae-info.org/ae/User/Voisin_Claire|accessdate=2015-09-18}}. In May 2016 she was elected as a foreign associate of the [[National Academy of Sciences]].{{citation|url=http://www.nasonline.org/news-and-multimedia/news/may-3-2016-NAS-Election.html|title=National Academy of Sciences Members and Foreign Associates Elected|department=News from the National Academy of Sciences|publisher=[[National Academy of Sciences]]|date=May 3, 2016|accessdate=2016-05-14}}. Also in 2016, she became the first female mathematician member of the [[Collège de France]] and is the first holder of the Chair of Algebraic Geometry.{{citation|url=http://www.academie-sciences.fr/fr/Membres-a-la-une/claire-voisin-nommee-titulaire-de-la-chaire-geometrie-algebrique-du-college-de-france.html|title=Claire Voisin nommée titulaire de la chaire Géométrie algébrique du Collège de France|publisher=Institut de France, Académie des sciences|date=April 27, 2016|accessdate=2016-06-10}}. She received the [[CNRS Gold medal|Gold medal]] of the [[French National Centre for Scientific Research]] (CNRS) in September 2016. The latter is the highest scientific research award in France.{{citation|url=http://www2.cnrs.fr/presse/communique/4701.htm|title=La médaille d'or 2016 du CNRS est attribuée à Claire Voisin, mathématicienne|publisher=French National Centre for Scientific Research (CNRS)|date=September 21, 2016|accessdate=2016-10-03}}. In 2017 she received the [[Shaw Prize]] in Mathematical Sciences.[http://www.shawprize.org/en/shaw.php?tmp=5&twoid=79&threeid=264&fourid=501 Shaw Prize 2017] ==Personal life== She is married to applied mathematician [[Jean-Michel Coron]]. They have five children.[http://webusers.imj-prg.fr/~claire.voisin/Articlesweb/noticevoisin.pdf ''Curriculum Vitae''] ==Selected publications== *''Hodge Theory and complex algebraic geometry.'' 2 vols., Cambridge University Press (Cambridge Studies in Advanced Mathematics), 2002, 2003, vol. 1, {{ISBN|0-521-71801-5}}.{{cite journal|author=Clemens, Herbert|authorlink=Herbert Clemens|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/2005-42-04/S0273-0979-05-01056-6/S0273-0979-05-01056-6.pdf|title=Review: ''Hodge theory and complex algebraic geometry I, II'' by Claire Voisin|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=2005|volume=42|issue=4|pages=507–520|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-05-01056-6}} *''Mirror Symmetry.'' AMS 1999, {{ISBN|0-8218-1947-X}}. *''Variations of Hodge Structure on Calabi Yau Threefolds.'' Edizioni Scuola Normale Superiore, 2007. *with Mark Green, J. Murre (eds.) ''Algebraic Cycles and Hodge Theory'', Lecture Notes in Mathematics 1594, Springer Verlag 1994 (CIME Lectures), containing article by Voisin: ''Transcendental methods in the study of algebraic cycles'' == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{MathGenealogy |id=84098}} *[http://webusers.imj-prg.fr/~claire.voisin/ Homepage] *[http://webusers.imj-prg.fr/~claire.voisin/Articlesweb/noticevoisin.pdf Curriculum Vitae] {{Shaw Prize laureates}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Voisin, Claire}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century French mathematicians]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:21st-century French mathematicians]] [[Category:Members of the French Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:University of Paris faculty]] [[Category:Clay Research Award recipients]] [[Category:Members of Academia Europaea]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:French women mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century women mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century women mathematicians]]

pages.text:
'''José Felipe Voloch''' (born 13 February 1963 in [[Rio de Janeiro]]) is a [[Brazil]]ian [[mathematician]] who works on [[number theory]] and [[algebraic geometry]]. He was professor at the [[University of Texas]]. Currently, he is a faculty member at Canterbury University.<ref>http://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/voloch/</ref>

Voloch earned his Ph.D. from the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1985 under the supervision of [[John William Scott Cassels]].<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=13154|title=José Felipe Voloch}}</ref>

He is a member of the [[Brazilian Academy of Sciences]].<ref name="ABC">[http://www.abc.org.br/resultado.php3?codigo=voloch&lang=en Brazilian Academy of Sciences] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610211642/http://www.abc.org.br/resultado.php3?codigo=voloch&lang=en |date=2015-06-10 }}</ref>

pages.title: Charles Weibel
pages.text:
[[File:Weibel 2004.jpg|thumb|Charles A. Weibel at [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach|Oberwolfach]] in 2004]]
'''Charles Alexander Weibel''' (born October 28, 1950 in [[Terre Haute]], [[Indiana]]) is an [[United States|American]] mathematician working on [[algebraic K-theory]], [[algebraic geometry]] and [[homological algebra]].

Weibel studied physics and mathematics at the [[University of Michigan]], earning [[bachelor's degree]]s in both subjects in 1972. He was awarded a [[master's degree]] by the [[University of Chicago]] in 1973 and achieved his doctorate in 1977 under the supervision of [[Richard Swan]] (''Homotopy in Algebraic K-Theory''). From 1970 to 1976 he was an "Operations Research Analyst" at [[Standard Oil]] in Indiana, and spent 1977–78 at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]]. In 1978 he became an [[assistant professor]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and in 1980 an assistant professor at [[Rutgers University]], where he was promoted to professor in 1989.

He joined [[Vladimir Voevodsky]] and [[Markus Rost]] in proving the (motivic) [[Bloch–Kato conjecture]] (2009).<ref>''The norm residue isomorphism theorem'', [[Journal of Topology]], Volume 2, 2009, pp. 346–372</ref> It is a generalization of the [[Milnor conjecture]] of algebraic K-theory, which was proved by Voevodsky in the 1990s. He was a visiting professor in 1992 at the [[University of Paris]] and 1993 at the [[University of Strasbourg]]. Since 1983 he has been an editor of the [[Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra]].

In 2014, he became a Fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2014-12-17</ref>

== Writings ==
* With [[Eric Friedlander]], ''An overview over algebraic K-theory'', in ''Algebraic K-theory and its applications'', World Scientific 1999, pp. 1–119 (1997 Trieste Lecture Notes)
* ''[http://www.math.rutgers.edu/~weibel/Kbook.html The K-Book, an introduction to algebraic K-theory]''
* With Carlo Mazza, [[Vladimir Voevodsky]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=gYSeAwAAQBAJ ''Lectures on Motivic Cohomology''], Clay Monographs in Mathematics, American Mathematical Society 2006
* ''An introduction to homological algebra'', Cambridge University Press 1994
* ''The proof of the Bloch-Kato conjecture'', Trieste Lectures 2007, ICTP Lecture Notes Series 23 (2008), 277–305
